urn:contentItem:5Y8W-0JH1-F03R-N4M0-00000-00NeurIPS requires AI researchers to account for societal impact and financial conflicts of interest2020-02-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:44ZLexisNexisNeurIPS requires AI researchers to account for societal impact and financial conflicts of interestKhari Johnson

Feb 24, 2020( VentureBeat: http://venturebeat.com/ Delivered by Newstex) For the first time ever, researchers who submit papers to NeurIPS, one of the biggest AI research conferences in the world, must now state the 'potential broader impact of their work' on society as well as any financial conflict of interest, conference organizers told VentureBeat. NeurIPS is one of the first and largest AI research conferences to enact the requirements. The social impact statement will require AI researchers to confront and account for both positive and negative potential outcomes of their work, while the financial disclosure requirement may illuminate the role industry and big tech companies play in the field. Financial disclosures must state both potential conflicts of interests directly related to the submitted research and any potential unrelated conflict of interest.

NeurIPS 2020 communications chair Michael Littman told VentureBeat in an email that the 'ethical aspects and future societal consequences' statements will be published with each paper. However, they'll appear only in the camera-ready versions of the papers so they do not compromise the double-blind nature of the reviewing process. Research with potential ethical concerns will be given special consideration.'Reviewers and area chairs' assessment will be done on the basis of technical contributions only. However, if a paper is flagged for potential ethical concerns, then the paper will be sent to another set of reviewers with expertise in ethics and machine learning. The final acceptance of these papers is contingent on the positive assessment by these second set of reviewers as well,' Littman said. At a town hall last year, NeurIPS 2019 organizers suggested[1] that researchers this year may be required to state their model's carbon footprint, perhaps using calculators like ML CO2 Impact[2]. The impact a model will have on climate change can certainly be categorized as related to 'future societal impact,' but no such explicit requirement is included in the 2020 call for papers. https://www.vbtransform.com/'The norms around the societal consequences statements are not yet well established,' Littman said. 'We expect them to take form over the next several conferences and, very likely, to evolve over time with the concerns of the society more broadly. Note that there are many papers submitted to the conference that are conceptual in nature and do not require the use of large scale computational resources, so this particular concern, while extremely important, is not universally relevant.' Responses to the new rules vary.To be clear, I don't think this is a positive step. Societal impacts of AI is a tough field, and there are researchers and organizations that study it professionally. Most authors do not have expertise in the area and won't do good enough scholarship to say something meaningful. — Roger Grosse (@RogerGrosse) February 20, 2020[3]Roger Grosse, a faculty member at the Vector Institute for AI at the University of Toronto, complained that the new policy will 'lead to trivialization of important issues.' Grosse is a member of CIFAR leadership[4] and suggested corporate sponsors be required to share statements about their broader impact on society. In recent years, NeurIPS has faced criticism for the growing role of the major AI research arms of tech giants like Google AI, OpenAI, and Facebook AI Research (FAIR). In response to Grosse's argument that social impact should be left to researchers who focus on ethics or social impact, Joe Redmon said he stopped doing computer vision research because of his concerns about the potential dangerous impacts it could have on the world. Redmon created the YOLO[5] real-time object detection system together with Ali Farhadi, whose company, Xnor, was recently acquired by Apple[6]. Redmon described himself as a person who used to buy into the myth that science is apolitical. He declared that virtually no facial recognition research would get published if the broader society impact was taken seriously.I stopped doing CV research because I saw the impact my work was having. I loved the work but the military applications and privacy concerns eventually became impossible to ignore.   https://t.co/DMa6evaQZr[7] — Joe Redmon (@pjreddie) February 20, 2020[8]Last month, Deborah Raji, a fellow at the AI Now Institute at New York University, introduced an internal auditing framework for businesses to evaluate the ethical performance of their AI systems and close what she and coauthors call an 'AI accountability gap.'[9] The framework draws on tools for documenting impact like data sheets for data sets and model cards from Google AI. It also draws on regulatory practices from other industries like aviation and pharmaceutical drug testing. 'I think there's a lot of things that we don't do that other fields do,' Raji told VentureBeat in a phone interview. Raji said requiring social impact statements at conferences like NeurIPS may be emerging in response to the publication of ethically questionable research at conferences in the past year, such as a comment-generating algorithm that can disseminate misinformation in social media. She calls the new rules a step in the right direction. 'Industry is just very present [in the AI research field], so the way that things get operationalized, the rapidness through which it enters the market and industry, is so quick that it makes sense for you to actually be thinking about how your work is going to be interpreted and how it's going to be used, and I think that forcing researchers to take the time to do that is going to be important with respect to getting them to be more reflective on the impact of their work,' she said. Raji calls attitudes that say only researchers focused on ethics or social impact should evaluate a model 'a misunderstanding of your responsibility as a researcher.' 'In my education, we weren't really given a vocabulary around any of this. I think that's why people are freaking out a little bit, but ultimately it's not that big a deal,' she said. Conference organizers shared new rules alongside a call for papers last week[10] for the 34th annual Neural Information Processing Systems conference (NeurIPS). The conference will take place in December in Vancouver, Canada. NeurIPS papers are due May 12. [ 1]:   https://venturebeat.com/2019/12/20/ai-weekly-machine-learnings-role-in-climate-change/ [ 2]:   https://venturebeat.com/2019/12/20/ai-weekly-machine-learnings-role-in-climate-change/ [ 3]:   https://twitter.com/RogerGrosse/status/1230509267230261248?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw [ 4]:   https://www.cifar.ca/ai/pan-canadian-artificial-intelligence-strategy [ 5]:   https://pjreddie.com/darknet/yolo/ [ 6]:   https://venturebeat.com/2020/01/15/apple-acquires-edge-ai-startup-xnor/ [ 7]:   https://t.co/DMa6evaQZr [ 8]:   https://twitter.com/pjreddie/status/1230524770350817280?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw [ 9]:   https://venturebeat.com/2020/01/30/google-researchers-release-audit-framework-to-close-ai-accountability-gap/ [ 10]:   https://nips.cc/Conferences/2020/CallForPapers

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RYH-CVX1-DY0W-44PT-00000-00Neutral good2018-03-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:44ZLexisNexisPg. 5Neutral goodCarl SegerstromPaonia, Colo.FULL TEXT

Western states lead the fight to maintain net neutrality

Late last year, the Federal Communications Commission voted 3-2 to disband protections for net neutrality, the principle that internet service providers cannot choose which websites to favor or block. The change gives internet service providers more opportunity to make money, but may hurt smaller businesses and internet users along the way.

Even though the West is home to some of the most important players in the tech industry, its rural areas often suffer from lack of internet access - a problem some argue could be solved by loosening net neutrality regulations. Open internet advocates, however, believe that net neutrality is essential to the free exchange of ideas and information on the internet.

There is broad bipartisan support for the regulations; a University of Maryland poll found more than 80 percent of respondents opposed repealing them. Now, Western states are leading the push for net neutrality, arguing that the regulations are necessary to foster innovation and prevent big corporations like AT&T and Comcast from monopolizing the web.

Montana's Democratic Gov. Steve Bullock was the first state leader to issue an executive order aimed at upholding net neutrality, and the attorneys general of Oregon, California, Washington and New Mexico have joined a nationwide lawsuit against the FCC. Six Western state legislatures are considering or have passed bills that would enforce net neutrality on a statewide level. By opposing the federal policy and enacting their own regulations, states can signal to big tech companies like Google, Facebook, Amazon and Netflix - which all support net neutrality - that they are friendly to the cause. "What states are responding to is a very public outcry for net neutrality," said Christopher Ali, a media studies professor at the University of Virginia.

The FCC's recent decision undid its own 2015 ruling classifying the internet as a telecommunications service, which gave the agency the authority to regulate internet providers and prevent them from discriminating against or favoring website content.

In Congress, the net neutrality debate has generally been split along party lines, with Republicans favoring less regulation and Democrats preferring stronger protections. Oregon Rep. Greg Walden, Nevada Sen. Dean Heller and Wyoming Sens. John Barrasso and Mike Enzi are some of the staunchest supporters of rolling back net neutrality rules. They and other critics argue that the FCC was overstepping its authority and that the new regulations were unnecessary. Lighter regulations, they say, would give internet providers more incentives to invest in rural communities.

A March 2016 policy paper from the Senate Republican Policy Committee, chaired by Barrasso, said, "FCC Chairman Wheeler's open internet order will stifle innovation and investment in internet infrastructure and jobs; create uncertainty; and lead to years of litigation."

Travis Kavulla, the vice chairman of Montana's Public Service Commission, said rural consumers could benefit from less regulation. For example, "Providers could partner with companies like Netflix to create cheaper internet packages." Kavulla added that regulators should keep a close eye on one-provider markets - and step in to protect consumers if necessary - but that they should wait for problems to arise rather than making restrictive laws beforehand.

In supporting net neutrality, states are thumbing their noses at the FCC, which had declared that states could not develop their own protections. On Jan. 22, Bullock issued an executive order declaring that Montana would not give contracts to internet providers that don't adhere to net neutrality principles. "There has been a lot of talk around the country about how to respond to the recent decision by (the) FCC," said Bullock. "It's time to actually do something about it," he said. He called on other states to follow Montana's lead, and New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo, D, quickly signed an executive order of his own.

Alaska, Idaho, Oregon and New Mexico have proposed legislation to protect net neutrality on a statewide basis. The California State Senate passed a bill on Jan. 29 that would introduce even stronger protections than those previously in place at the FCC; the bill now awaits passage in the state Assembly. The Washington Legislature overwhelmingly passed a bill on Feb. 27 that prevents internet providers in the state from slowing down or blocking legal content or creating "fast lanes" that prioritize paid content. Attorneys general from Oregon, California, Washington and New Mexico have joined a lawsuit with 17 other states and Washington, D.C., that argues the FCC's recent ruling was not justified and that the changes were not supported by sufficient legal evidence.

Having a patchwork of net neutrality protections that varies by state is not the ideal way to regulate the internet, but it could become the status quo if state and federal lawmakers continue to butt heads. The conflict is the latest example of states pushing back against the Trump administration's broad deregulatory agenda. Western states have been at the forefront of addressing climate change after Trump signaled his intent to pull out of the Paris Climate Accord, and they seem poised to continue the push for net neutrality. "We can't wait for folks in Washington, D.C., to come to their senses and reinstate these rules," said Bullock.

Carl Segerstrom is an editorial intern at High Country News. t @carlschirps

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5F75-X3N1-JD2T-F49G-00000-00Never-Ending Circle of Debt; Picking Up The Pieces; Super Bowl Debbie Downer; Travel Chaos; The $4 Trillion Budget; Ale To The Chief;2015-02-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:44ZLexisNexisNever-Ending Circle of Debt; Picking Up The Pieces; Super Bowl Debbie Downer; Travel Chaos; The $4 Trillion Budget; Ale To The Chief;

MELISSA FRANCIS, MONEY HOST: The president unveiling his megabudget. He's going to add $6 trillion to our national debt. Perfect. And guess who'll be paying that off -- young people in this country. More burdened ever before, they are making thousands less than their parents did decades ago.

And speaking of big budgets? How about the price tags of those Super Bowl ads? Most of that money spent depressing us. We're going to dig into that one.

And good luck getting back from the big game. Dangerous weather in some parts of the country causing travel chaos everywhere. Because even when they say it's not, it's always about money.

The $4 trillion budget. President Obama unveiling his proposal earlier today, saying the country can afford the hefty price tag.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PRES. BARACK OBAMA, UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: Since I took office we have cut our deficits by about two-thirds. That's the fastest period of sustained deficit reduction since after the demobilization at the end of World War II. So we can afford to make these invests while remaining fiscally responsible.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

FRANCIS: It's interesting considering the White House expects it to add nearly $6 trillion to the national debt over the next decade.

Let's bring in today's panel. James Freeman of -- from the "Wall Street Journal". Todd Starnes is from Fox News Radio. John Lonski is here as well from Moody's. You're their chief economist. All you take the crack out of it. Can we afford this -- no problem?

JOHN LONSKI, MOODY'S CHIEF ECONOMIST: Well, maybe you can afford it today but if you look forward at the funding demands from the retirement of a -- forthcoming retirement of Baby Boomers, a pressure being placed on Medicare along with us, the unknown costs of the Affordable Care Act -- never mind the possibility of another recession -- no, you cannot afford it longer term.

FRANCIS: James, I don't even think we can afford it today.

JAMES FREEMAN, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL ASSISTANT EDITOR: Yeah. And just to be clear, the -- this White House math you need to translate a little. When he's saying.

FRANCIS: Yes, please.

FREEMAN: . we've done a great job.

FRANCIS: Yes, please.

FREEMAN: . of deficit reduction, historic, what he leaves out that first year of '09 with the stimulus was highest deficit since World War II. So the fact that he gave.

FRANCIS: He's using that as base..

FREEMAN: Right. He gave us four straight years of trillion plus deficits. And now that it's gone down to 500,000 million.

FRANCIS: Right.

FREEMAN: . in any other time.

FRANCIS: Would be horrible?

FREEMAN: . would be considered horrible and irresponsible.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

FREEMAN: . he is taking credit for the reduction. But no entitlement reform in this budget.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

BARNES: You bet.

FRANCIS: Wisconsin governor, Scott Walker, getting some major love from the Hawkeye State. A new poll from the Des Moines register shows walker leading the way with likely Iowa caucus voters at 15 percent. Senator Rand Paul right on his heels with 14 percent. It is worth noting that this poll was done before Mitt Romney called it quits. Todd Starnes and John Lonski are back to discuss this. Todd, what do you think is this surprising to you that Scott was -- kind of his neck on the woods?

STARNES: You know, it is his neck of the woods. But when you really step back and look at Scott walker and his story and what he's able to accomplish in Wisconsin, this guy really could be a contender. So I'm excited to see how he does as more people get to know his story and what he did in Wisconsin.

FRANCIS: Yeah, John, what do you think its economics would mean for the country?

LONSKI: Well, I think his performance in Wisconsin has been excellent from the viewpoint of the markets.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

LONSKI: Right now, it cost only $32 to insure $10,000 worth of Wisconsin government debt. In neighboring Illinois, that premium is over $190. He's done a great job. And this is a difficult.

FRANCIS: So that's a wonderful point. So explaining to our audience what that means is that he is more credit worthy because of what he has done in the state and how.

LONSKI: Precisely.

FRANCIS: . he tights the budget.

LONSKI: He knows how to run a government and how to control the budget. And that's something I think a lot of Americans very much want from Washington.

FRANCIS: And nobody in Washington seems to know how to do it all. So he could really bring that math to D.C. That's a good point. All right. Meanwhile, a non-flattering profile of Jeb Bush testing the theory that all press is good press. The "Boston Globe" publishing a lengthy write-up on Bush's prep school years with classmates alleging that Bush was a heavy pot smoker and at times he was even a bully which if you have kids right now, you know, that's the worst thing that you could say about a child right now, that they are a bully. I mean that's like one of the big things.

STARNES: You know, I had a chance to read this piece in the "Boston Globe", Melissa.

FRANCIS: Did you? Yeah.

STARNES: It's not like he was sitting in his dorm room listening to, you know, barbata rock (ph) and smoking crack. You know, the guy was smoking pot. And maybe he pushed around a couple kids every now and again. They said he was the tallest kid in campus. So he was a little bit of imposing figure.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

STARNES: . but look, they did the same thing with Mitt Romney. The thing that gets me is the double standard here. The mainstream media go after the Republicans but they give the Democrats a pass.

FRANCIS: Well, I mean he was in high school.

LONSKI: Oh, yeah.

FRANCIS: I'm so glad I didn't do anything bad in high school. I mean, right.

LONSKI: Neither did I, Melissa.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

LONSKI: But the reality is I'd be a hypocrite if I stated that. So we're all hypocrites. You know, we all tell our children not to make the mistakes we made.

FRANCIS: Right.

LONSKI: But that does not make us hypocrites.

FRANCIS: Yeah. No. That's amazing. Meanwhile, the governor Chris Christie meeting with British prime minister David Cameron in London today. The rest of the country, though, they had no idea who he was. A 63-year-old nurse summing up her feelings for Christie by saying, quote, "I enjoyed American politics, but I've never heard of him." She says she enjoys American politics like, "They're amusing from afar -- those American politics." You know, it (inaudible) you guys are idiots but I do not know who this joker is. Like that's basically she said. What do you think, John?

LONSKI: Well, You know, it's not surprising. They don't know who he is because he hasn't done that great of a job controlling New Jersey's budget, you know, what I referred to earlier.

FRANCIS: I don't think they have a clue about New Jersey's budget.

LONSKI: Well, why.

FRANCIS: I don't know local politicians.

LONSKI: He can't take care of his own house.

FRANCIS: Right.

LONSKI: I mean why should you care about him on the global stage?

STARNES: Yeah. I mean here, he is an anomaly because he hollers at people he doesn't like. They do that all the time.

FRANCIS: That is right.

STARNES: So that's a few things but.

FRANCIS: That's right. If you watch the House of Parliament get together and they're all screaming at each other.

STARNES: They wear haltered wig. That's what I want to know.

FRANCIS: Yes. I don't know.

STARNES: How he might go to look with it (ph)?

FRANCIS: I don't know. He's trying to look like he has international experience or he can -- and everybody's like. "Who is this guy?"

STARNES: International mystery.

FRANCIS: Right. He didn't wear the red sweater so that counts for something. Thanks, guys. Heading in to the last hour of trading, let's check in with Liz Claman and see what she's got coming up with her program. Liz.

LIZ CLAMAN, COUNTDOWN HOST: Well, you just were talking about the Super Bowl commercials, which ones hit it, which ones didn't. Who won the social media show? How about that? Who stole that show? Was it Facebook or Twitter? There is a huge discrepancy, trust me, between the two numbers. Wait until you hear who comes out on top.

And on top of that, these two experts that we have coming in are going to talk about who stole the actual commercial show. And they are experts. Netbase Aggregates -- a lot of the data. Peter Caswell, their smarty pants guy, he actually has some hard data on who might have won the commercials in here.

And Lance Ulanoff, Mashable's editor-at-large is very opinionated. And he has a very good sense of the winners there.

And college students, Melissa, you know they're in the prime of their life. At least, Amazon Prime thinks they are. They are striking deals with universities now to make sure that college kids have the most robin as they need overnight. Yes, Amazon Prime hooking up with all kinds of universities and colleges to grab the college dollars. They need the student body money, Melissa.

Is this going to be big? Well, Ripley MacDonald of Amazon thinks so. He's the direct or of student programs. That plus the S&P hits a 2015 low. So we're going to be looking at the markets and asking this question of our traders. Time to go to cash? Maybe, maybe not.

FRANCIS: Liz, sounds like a great show. I can't wait.

CLAMAN: OK.

FRANCIS: The Super Bowl going head to head with Hollywood. "American Sniper" is still raking in the dough.

Plus, the Super Bowl hang over. Hopefully, you didn't called out sick today because if you did, you are not alone and we're all very suspicious. You can never have too much money.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: Whether it's on Wall Street or Main Street, here's who's making and losing money today -- anyone with a piece of Shake Shack. The stock hitting a new low after more than doubling during it's debut last week. That is not so great news for founder Danny Meyer who has more than 7 million shares meaning he lost $9 million since waking up. At least he has delicious burgers to make him feel better. We went to Shake Shack this weekend, it was awesome.

Plus, working at the Super Bowl -- Missy Elliott. Spotify reporting a streaming increase for the rapper. Her songs are up nearly 700 percent after the game. Missy's hit song, "Lose Control" is up more than 1300 percent.

Headliner, Katy Perry seeing an overall increase around 85 percent for her music. And "American Sniper" tops the Box Office again. The Clint Eastwood film raking in more than $30 million this weekend. That brings to the total gross of nearly $250 million. Wow. They're doing well with that one.

Now, for a little fun with spare change. If you are watching this show from your couch at home, you are not alone. Nearly, 1.5 million Americans are calling out sick today. We're not buying it. Bruce is back with me.

So Bruce, I love this. It is the most common day of the year to call in sick because it is the first Monday in February. People love to call on sick on Mondays because it just makes sense your week is not quite over. It's the dead of winter. We have a storm going on here on the northeast. And it's the day it's the day after the Super Bowl. In my book, anyone who called in sick today, I'm sorry, looks completely bogus. You're better off coming in to work vomiting on someone and going home, right?

TURKEL: Absolutely. That was my dad saying, "Anybody who calls in sick on Monday is not sick." We had two in our office but they had good excuses. Allison had a baby on Friday. Roberto is injury duty. So my office is cool.

FRANCIS: Right.

TURKEL: I think the rest of them, yeah, it's kind of bogus.

FRANCIS: It's a little bogus.1.5 million people are expected to call in sick today. 4.4 million arrived late.

TURKEL: And hung over.

FRANCIS: And hung over because the Super Bowl was awesome and you had to watch it to the end. Some good excuses that we've heard along the way. My uniform caught fire when I put it in the microwave to dry. I like that one. I accidentally got on a plane. Yup, me too. That's a good one.

TURKEL: The (inaudible) allows that everyday.

FRANCIS: Yes, right. Exactly. What are some good ones that you've heard, Bruce?

TURKEL: The best ones I've heard is the people who call up and try to sound sick and they're talking, "You know, I can't come in." You don't sound sick. And you're trying so hard.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

TURKEL: . to sound sick. But you know, if you stayed out and had a lot to drink, you woke up a little green and it's my office -- stay away. I don't like your idea of coming in and throwing up on my desk. I can do it without them.

FRANCIS: Yeah. I don't know. I mean just for myself, if you don't want to want to look like you're calling out and it's not true.

TURKEL: Prove it.

FRANCIS: . have you ever called in sick on Super Bowl Monday? Bruce, you strike me as someone who would never call in sick no matter what.

TURKEL: Never. Never.

FRANCIS: No?

TURKEL: Absolutely not.

FRANCIS: Maybe the NFL should move the game to Saturday night.

TURKEL: Well, I think they figured out when they can get the highest viewership. Remember, Saturday night is a profitable night for a lot of reasons. Sunday night is not. And so, they show up on Sunday. They get the highest ratings of any show in history. I think they figured out that right. And by the way, the NFL does not care if your employees don't show up for work the next day.

FRANCIS: No. They definitely -- I mean they focus at the victory because you're at home watching television.

TURKEL: Of course.

FRANCIS: So you could be watching other NFL shows, NFL network. I mean it's a win-win all the way around. Bruce Turkel, thank you so much.

TURKEL: Thank you, Melissa.

FRANCIS: So we ask what crazy excuses you've heard for not coming in to work. And you guys didn't disappoint us. On Facebook, Stephanie writes, "Once I said my cat was sick because I wanted to enjoy the freakish plenty fall Seattle day in my new sports car."

And Andy tweets, "I dreamed I was fired so I stayed home." That was an excuse that he used. Jonathan says, "I didn't use this myself." Sure, Jonathan. "But a coworker once used, my hair hurts." I loved that one. That's somebody who wants to be fired. My hair hurts.

Follow me on Twitter @melissaafrancis or like me on facebook.com/MelissaFrancisFox. If you follow me on Twitter could really fun especially when something bad happens at a restaurant. I'm just saying.

They may be beautiful, but they're certainly not rich. Young people finally get proved that mom and dad had it easier. So maybe a little help with that cellphone bill isn't out of the question. At the end of the day, it's all about money -- money and Monday.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: Celebrities they are just like us. The night before John Legend's super model wife, Chrissy Teigen joined Kim and Kanye West for a quality dinner. Check it out. The foursome hit up a nearby waffle house where Kanye West reported sought (ph) for the entire meal. Like that's really a surprise. So you think he's more of a pancakes or scrambled eggs kind of guy? Why would you not want to go to waffle house for dinner? He's so pouty.

All right. Crashing student debts. Now, that millennials are making $2,000 less than their parents did at their age, recently released senses data reveals that young people basically everywhere except on the east coast and had seen their earnings drop since 1980. James and John are back with us. Not really surprised but depressing nonetheless. James.

FREEMAN: It is depressing. I think it goes back to the story that started your broadcast, which is you cannot go after investment and business income because that is the money that funds technology and equipment, which is what allows people to make more money. So if you want these kids to have more salaries, you've to allow businesses to put the technology into the workplace that will justify those higher salaries.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

LONSKI: You've got to be careful not to over regulate the economy because the reality today is that these young people will be facing every increasing competition from the skilled and always cheaper workforce of emerging market countries.

FRANCIS: Yeah. And I mean if you look at this as a parent who has no control over those kind of things other than your vote which you have -- but it can be so frustrating to watch our politicians screw things up -- what my takeaway from this is I got to stir my kids towards the jobs where they can actually make money more than ever. You know, look out in the future and -- they got to learn to code and they've got to get out there and do the things that are going to help them because kids are falling behind right?

FREEMAN: Well, you want skills that can give them a lot of options. But I think the problem right now it's policy and yes, part of it is K-12 education. But the big part is we're not seeing business creation because we don't have an environment that lets people grow without taxation and regulation. And that really is a -- it's the irony of the Obama era. All the people that he talks about helping.

FRANCIS: Right.

FREEMAN: . have had terrible time since he was elected.

FRANCIS: Right, John? Yeah.

LONSKI: He's exactly right. That's a sad story because it's actually the lower classes that have feared the worst over the last eight years or so.

FRANCIS: Yeah. Absolutely. All right, gentlemen. Thanks to both of you. I wanted to show you something fun before we go. Bruce Turkel sent this to me when we were doing our Super Bowl segment. Take a look that. That's Katy Perry in her costume from last night. Right next to her that's Will Ferrell from "Blades of Glory".

I think Katy may have borrowed the costume. What do you think, James?

FREEMAN: Yeah. It's a classic. I mean not quite on the level (inaudible) but it certainly.

FRANCIS: That's right.

FREEMAN: . a nommage at the Super Bowl.

FRANCIS: Fabulous. I know. John, you want to get in there?

LONSKI: In this side of economy, you got to be much more creative. (inaudible)

FRANCIS: I love it. Pretty facts. Economics no matter what. My head is off to you, John Lonski. Thank you. That's all the money we have for you. Here's Liz.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5KRW-JYX1-DY0W-422M-00000-00Never-Ending Circle of Debt; Picking Up The Pieces; Super Bowl Debbie Downer; Travel Chaos; The $4 Trillion Budget; Ale To The Chief;2015-02-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:44ZLexisNexisNever-Ending Circle of Debt; Picking Up The Pieces; Super Bowl Debbie Downer; Travel Chaos; The $4 Trillion Budget; Ale To The Chief;LanhamFULL TEXT

MELISSA FRANCIS, MONEY HOST: The president unveiling his megabudget. He's going to add $6 trillion to our national debt. Perfect. And guess who'll be paying that off -- young people in this country. More burdened ever before, they are making thousands less than their parents did decades ago.

And speaking of big budgets? How about the price tags of those Super Bowl ads? Most of that money spent depressing us. We're going to dig into that one.

And good luck getting back from the big game. Dangerous weather in some parts of the country causing travel chaos everywhere. Because even when they say it's not, it's always about money.

The $4 trillion budget. President Obama unveiling his proposal earlier today, saying the country can afford the hefty price tag.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PRES. BARACK OBAMA, UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: Since I took office we have cut our deficits by about two-thirds. That's the fastest period of sustained deficit reduction since after the demobilization at the end of World War II. So we can afford to make these invests while remaining fiscally responsible.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

FRANCIS: It's interesting considering the White House expects it to add nearly $6 trillion to the national debt over the next decade.

Let's bring in today's panel. James Freeman of -- from the "Wall Street Journal". Todd Starnes is from Fox News Radio. John Lonski is here as well from Moody's. You're their chief economist. All you take the crack out of it. Can we afford this -- no problem?

JOHN LONSKI, MOODY'S CHIEF ECONOMIST: Well, maybe you can afford it today but if you look forward at the funding demands from the retirement of a -- forthcoming retirement of Baby Boomers, a pressure being placed on Medicare along with us, the unknown costs of the Affordable Care Act -- never mind the possibility of another recession -- no, you cannot afford it longer term.

FRANCIS: James, I don't even think we can afford it today.

JAMES FREEMAN, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL ASSISTANT EDITOR: Yeah. And just to be clear, the -- this White House math you need to translate a little. When he's saying.

FRANCIS: Yes, please.

FREEMAN: . we've done a great job.

FRANCIS: Yes, please.

FREEMAN: . of deficit reduction, historic, what he leaves out that first year of '09 with the stimulus was highest deficit since World War II. So the fact that he gave.

FRANCIS: He's using that as base..

FREEMAN: Right. He gave us four straight years of trillion plus deficits. And now that it's gone down to 500,000 million.

FRANCIS: Right.

FREEMAN: . in any other time.

FRANCIS: Would be horrible?

FREEMAN: . would be considered horrible and irresponsible.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

FREEMAN: . he is taking credit for the reduction. But no entitlement reform in this budget.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

FREEMAN: So when we talk about future problems, no effort to fix them along with all the spending.

FRANCIS: No. And, Todd, you know, he's talking about taxing U.S. companies on overseas profits saying they should be paying their fair share. I love it when we say things like that. We're one of only countries in the world that wants to do something like this -- tax companies on their overseas profits. So it's basically unheard of around the globe.

TODD STARNES, FOX NEWS & COMMENTARY HOST: That's right. And you'll hear this president also say that he wants to look after the middle class. Well, middle class incomes under this president have gone down $4,000 annually. This is a very, very troubling time for American families.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

STARNES: And quite frankly, I don't any anybody is looking out for the working man in America.

FRANCIS: Yeah. Meanwhile, "Ale to the chief", NBC asking the really tough questions during the Super Bowl interview with President Obama.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

OBAMA: We make beer -- first president since George Washington to make some booze in the White House. Let's taste it.

SAVANNAH GUTHRIE, NBC NEWS ANCHOR: Right. Well, I'll let.

OBAMA: It's been well-reviewed.

GUTHRIE: . football or basketball?

OBAMA: I'm still a basketball guy but I love football.

GUTHRIE: Offense or defense?

OBAMA: Always offense.

GUTHRIE: Wings or chips and guac?

OBAMA: Now, that's tough. You know, I'm going chips and guac. I'm a fanatic about guac.

GUTHRIE: Hillary Clinton or Joe Biden?

OBAMA: Love them both.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

STARNES: Oh, Geezle (ph).

FRANCIS: Wow. I mean it makes GloZell look hard-hitting. Right? I mean doesn't it make you hunger for the green lipstick again? I mean, she really -- wow. Yeah. Impressed, Todd?

STARNES: OK. For the record here, let's do some history. And the president seems to thinks we still have 57 states. President Washington did not live in.

FRANCIS: Right.

STARNES: . the White House. So Mr. President, let's do some history there -- history research. Here is the issue I have. Aside from the fact that you're right, GloZell asked a more hard-hitting questions than Savannah Guthrie did, the bigger issue here is the president and the image he conveys here. He is hoisting and zipping a glass of organic honey ale.

FRANCIS: Yes.

STARNES: . with pinky finger extended.

FREEMAN: Yeah.

STARNES: What kind of message does that send our enemies?

FRANCIS: James, don't you do that?

FREEMAN: Not.

FRANCIS: No?

FREEMAN: . well, you just kind of knew it was going to be a pumpkin or honey flavored ale.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

FREEMAN: . but the.

FRANCIS: You should have that feeling.

FREEMAN: .. talking about broadcast history, back when Fox had the game last year, you had O'Reilly asking about the IRS.

FRANCIS: Right.

FREEMAN: . asking him about the rollout of the health care website. So, yeah.

FRANCIS: Not.

FREEMAN: . big contrast in the journalistic coverage.

FRANCIS: Not guac versus wings? You don't think that is presidential, John?

LONSKI: This is a great example of not wasting your time watching pre-game shows.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

LONSKI: . it's a perfect example of it.

FRANCIS: Yeah. Absolutely.

STARNES: Can I ask you this though?

FRANCIS: Yeah.

STARNES: Did anyone else notice that Savannah Guthrie, the female anchor - - they decided to do interview in a kitchen? I mean what sort of optics does send this whole war on women?

FRANCIS: There you go. I love it. All right. And ratings record for the Super Bowl -- not that interview, but for the Super Bowl itself. The dramatic finish helping the event score the highest overnight rating in history -- up 4 percent from last year. So if you leaped through that interview at beginning -- and I got to tell you I didn't even watch it, I watched parts of it later all I could stomach -- but the game was phenomenal. James. What did you think?

FREEMAN: Yeah.

FRANCIS: You loved the game?

FREEMAN: Until the end.

FRANCIS: I saw you in the hallway. You looked a little bitter.

FREEMAN: Absolutely. And I'm still bitter. I.

FRANCIS: I feel like you're a Seahawks guy.

FREEMAN: . this is a team -- this is basically the greatest team in the last 15 years, now, caught twice breaking the rules. And you could argue about.

FRANCIS: Come on.

FREEMAN: . intent. You can argue about who was it? Was it the equipment guy or whatever? But I don't think that's.

FRANCIS: The lone wolf ball boy in the bathroom.

STARNES: By the way.

FRANCIS: Yes.

STARNES: . on plus side, did you see.

FRANCIS: Yes.

STARNES: . Katy Perry straddling the mechanical lion there? Did you catch the nuance on field? She was parading through a field of inflated balls.

FRANCIS: Wow. John Lonski.

STARNES: I don't know what that means.

FRANCIS: . you want to come out and try to top that joke?

LONSKI: Well, I can't top that one but you have to admit, the Patriots denied everything -- any wrongdoing. They had no knowledge of it.

FRANCIS: Yes. So you're counting them a break. You think that -- and you're totally ignoring inflated balls coming?

LONSKI: The eye of the tiger.

FREEMAN: No one disputes the inflation of the balls were.

FRANCIS: Right. All right.

STARNES: Either fireworks otherwise.

FRANCIS: Let's do something serious here. Oil staging a rally, currently up for the third day in a row. That is shockingly crude's longest winning streak more than five months. John, I feel you'll be on solid ground with this one -- for oil.

LONSKI: Yeah. Production.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

LONSKI: . production are showing their.

FRANCIS: There you go.

LONSKI: . back on prices. You've really cut back on rig count in the United States -- down 20 percent to 30 percent. Capital spending by oil companies is dropping.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

LONSKI: So it follows that oil prices begin to move higher.

FRANCIS: A lot of people talking about these strikes that are going on at refineries around the country. And that -- I mean it's surprising to see crude rally in the face of that because normally, it would mean there'd be less demand for crude oil. So crude would fall, if refineries are on strike. It could be bad news for consumers, right, James.

FREEMAN: Yeah. I think John is solid on every topic for the record.

FRANCIS: Yes. That's right. Yes.

FREEMAN: But we, you know, we could see price rises here. You would talk about some reduction in drilling in North America. And of course if strikes threaten production, that's going to make the price go up.

FRANCIS: OK. This is a big story. Tale of two groundhogs today. Punxsutawney Phil seeing a shadow this morning seeing six more weeks of winter. But the groundhog of record in my book is Staten Island Chuck, he is predicting the end of winter. Although, we don't know who that really is because of course Mayor de Blasio killed Staten Island Chuck last year when he dropped him on his head. It turns out that wasn't even Staten Island Chuck, it was his sister Charlotte that, you know, capped last year in the middle of this whole thing.

And here we go. We're going to see it. This is where he killed it. So the groundhog died later that night. So the new replacement this year was safely in a glass box to make sure that it didn't get killed by the mayor which was really smart move. I would hide in a glass box as well.

STARNES: Now, my groundhog is General Beauregard Lee in the Southern States of Atlanta.

FRANCIS: I'm sorry, who?

STARNES: General Beauregard Lee. Are you not familiar with this?

FRANCIS: No.

STARNES: Everybody below the Mason-Dixon Line.

FRANCIS: OK.

STARNES: . looks to General Lee to determine weather. And he sided with Staten Island Chuck there.

FRANCIS: Really?

STARNES: So you got the Yankees and the southerners.

FRANCIS: You think it is over?

STARNES: I think so.

FRANCIS: Is he afraid of Mayor de Blasio? Does he know about the murder that happened last year?

TURKEL: Absolutely. That was my dad saying, "Anybody who calls in sick on Monday is not sick." We had two in our office but they had good excuses. Allison had a baby on Friday. Roberto is injury duty. So my office is cool.

FRANCIS: Right.

TURKEL: I think the rest of them, yeah, it's kind of bogus.

FRANCIS: It's a little bogus.1.5 million people are expected to call in sick today. 4.4 million arrived late.

TURKEL: And hung over.

FRANCIS: And hung over because the Super Bowl was awesome and you had to watch it to the end. Some good excuses that we've heard along the way. My uniform caught fire when I put it in the microwave to dry. I like that one. I accidentally got on a plane. Yup, me too. That's a good one.

TURKEL: The (inaudible) allows that everyday.

FRANCIS: Yes, right. Exactly. What are some good ones that you've heard, Bruce?

TURKEL: The best ones I've heard is the people who call up and try to sound sick and they're talking, "You know, I can't come in." You don't sound sick. And you're trying so hard.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

TURKEL: . to sound sick. But you know, if you stayed out and had a lot to drink, you woke up a little green and it's my office -- stay away. I don't like your idea of coming in and throwing up on my desk. I can do it without them.

FRANCIS: Yeah. I don't know. I mean just for myself, if you don't want to want to look like you're calling out and it's not true.

TURKEL: Prove it.

FRANCIS: . have you ever called in sick on Super Bowl Monday? Bruce, you strike me as someone who would never call in sick no matter what.

TURKEL: Never. Never.

FRANCIS: No?

TURKEL: Absolutely not.

FRANCIS: Maybe the NFL should move the game to Saturday night.

TURKEL: Well, I think they figured out when they can get the highest viewership. Remember, Saturday night is a profitable night for a lot of reasons. Sunday night is not. And so, they show up on Sunday. They get the highest ratings of any show in history. I think they figured out that right. And by the way, the NFL does not care if your employees don't show up for work the next day.

FRANCIS: No. They definitely -- I mean they focus at the victory because you're at home watching television.

TURKEL: Of course.

FRANCIS: So you could be watching other NFL shows, NFL network. I mean it's a win-win all the way around. Bruce Turkel, thank you so much.

TURKEL: Thank you, Melissa.

FRANCIS: So we ask what crazy excuses you've heard for not coming in to work. And you guys didn't disappoint us. On Facebook, Stephanie writes, "Once I said my cat was sick because I wanted to enjoy the freakish plenty fall Seattle day in my new sports car."

And Andy tweets, "I dreamed I was fired so I stayed home." That was an excuse that he used. Jonathan says, "I didn't use this myself." Sure, Jonathan. "But a coworker once used, my hair hurts." I loved that one. That's somebody who wants to be fired. My hair hurts.

Follow me on Twitter @melissaafrancis or like me on facebook.com/MelissaFrancisFox. If you follow me on Twitter could really fun especially when something bad happens at a restaurant. I'm just saying.

They may be beautiful, but they're certainly not rich. Young people finally get proved that mom and dad had it easier. So maybe a little help with that cellphone bill isn't out of the question. At the end of the day, it's all about money -- money and Monday.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

FRANCIS: Celebrities they are just like us. The night before John Legend's super model wife, Chrissy Teigen joined Kim and Kanye West for a quality dinner. Check it out. The foursome hit up a nearby waffle house where Kanye West reported sought (ph) for the entire meal. Like that's really a surprise. So you think he's more of a pancakes or scrambled eggs kind of guy? Why would you not want to go to waffle house for dinner? He's so pouty.

All right. Crashing student debts. Now, that millennials are making $2,000 less than their parents did at their age, recently released senses data reveals that young people basically everywhere except on the east coast and had seen their earnings drop since 1980. James and John are back with us. Not really surprised but depressing nonetheless. James.

FREEMAN: It is depressing. I think it goes back to the story that started your broadcast, which is you cannot go after investment and business income because that is the money that funds technology and equipment, which is what allows people to make more money. So if you want these kids to have more salaries, you've to allow businesses to put the technology into the workplace that will justify those higher salaries.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

LONSKI: You've got to be careful not to over regulate the economy because the reality today is that these young people will be facing every increasing competition from the skilled and always cheaper workforce of emerging market countries.

FRANCIS: Yeah. And I mean if you look at this as a parent who has no control over those kind of things other than your vote which you have -- but it can be so frustrating to watch our politicians screw things up -- what my takeaway from this is I got to stir my kids towards the jobs where they can actually make money more than ever. You know, look out in the future and -- they got to learn to code and they've got to get out there and do the things that are going to help them because kids are falling behind right?

FREEMAN: Well, you want skills that can give them a lot of options. But I think the problem right now it's policy and yes, part of it is K-12 education. But the big part is we're not seeing business creation because we don't have an environment that lets people grow without taxation and regulation. And that really is a -- it's the irony of the Obama era. All the people that he talks about helping.

FRANCIS: Right.

FREEMAN: . have had terrible time since he was elected.

FRANCIS: Right, John? Yeah.

LONSKI: He's exactly right. That's a sad story because it's actually the lower classes that have feared the worst over the last eight years or so.

FRANCIS: Yeah. Absolutely. All right, gentlemen. Thanks to both of you. I wanted to show you something fun before we go. Bruce Turkel sent this to me when we were doing our Super Bowl segment. Take a look that. That's Katy Perry in her costume from last night. Right next to her that's Will Ferrell from "Blades of Glory".

I think Katy may have borrowed the costume. What do you think, James?

FREEMAN: Yeah. It's a classic. I mean not quite on the level (inaudible) but it certainly.

FRANCIS: That's right.

FREEMAN: . a nommage at the Super Bowl.

FRANCIS: Fabulous. I know. John, you want to get in there?

LONSKI: In this side of economy, you got to be much more creative. (inaudible)

FRANCIS: I love it. Pretty facts. Economics no matter what. My head is off to you, John Lonski. Thank you. That's all the money we have for you. Here's Liz.

END

urn:contentItem:5F6Y-4GT1-JB20-G3VD-00000-00Never-Ending Circle of Debt; Picking Up The Pieces; Super Bowl Debbie Downer; Travel Chaos; The $4 Trillion Budget; Ale To The Chief; Pres. "Super Bowl" Interview; Super Bowl Ratings Record; Oil Stages A Rally; Groundhog Day Phil Vs. Chuck; Keep Your Shovels Close; Under Your Skin; Exxon Leads Energy Higher; Netflix Seeks $1B in Funds; The Almost- Fence Jumper; Measles Outbreak Worsening; The Young and The Broke; Verizon Close to Asset Sales; Tired Of Austerity; Croatia Wipes Out Debt; Chip & Skin Technology; Measles Warning From CDC; The Vaccination Debate; Fry Me A River; It's Nacho Fault; Super Bowl Champs; Ad Winners & Losers; McDonald's Big Miss; Jeb and Flow; Mr. West Is In The Building; Walker, Paul Lead In Iowa; When Bush Comes To Shove; Brit While You're Ahead?; More Success For "Sniper"; Shake Shacked; Super Bowl Boost; Millenials Thin Wallets; Crying Over Spilled Syrup?; The Young And The Broke2015-02-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:44ZLexisNexisMONEY2:00 PM ESTJames Freeman, John Lonski, Devi Nampiaparampil, Bruce TurkelNEWSInternational020201cb.230Never-Ending Circle of Debt; Picking Up The Pieces; Super Bowl Debbie Downer; Travel Chaos; The $4 Trillion Budget; Ale To The Chief; Pres. "Super Bowl" Interview; Super Bowl Ratings Record; Oil Stages A Rally; Groundhog Day Phil Vs. Chuck; Keep Your Shovels Close; Under Your Skin; Exxon Leads Energy Higher; Netflix Seeks $1B in Funds; The Almost- Fence Jumper; Measles Outbreak Worsening; The Young and The Broke; Verizon Close to Asset Sales; Tired Of Austerity; Croatia Wipes Out Debt; Chip & Skin Technology; Measles Warning From CDC; The Vaccination Debate; Fry Me A River; It's Nacho Fault; Super Bowl Champs; Ad Winners & Losers; McDonald's Big Miss; Jeb and Flow; Mr. West Is In The Building; Walker, Paul Lead In Iowa; When Bush Comes To Shove; Brit While You're Ahead?; More Success For "Sniper"; Shake Shacked; Super Bowl Boost; Millenials Thin Wallets; Crying Over Spilled Syrup?; The Young And The BrokeMelissa Francis, Todd Starnes, Rick Leventhal, Jeff Flock, Nicole Petallides, Rich Edson, Peter Barnes, Liz Claman

MELISSA FRANCIS, MONEY HOST: The president unveiling his megabudget. He's going to add $6 trillion to our national debt. Perfect. And guess who'll be paying that off -- young people in this country. More burdened ever before, they are making thousands less than their parents did decades ago.

And speaking of big budgets? How about the price tags of those Super Bowl ads? Most of that money spent depressing us. We're going to dig into that one.

And good luck getting back from the big game. Dangerous weather in some parts of the country causing travel chaos everywhere. Because even when they say it's not, it's always about money.

The $4 trillion budget. President Obama unveiling his proposal earlier today, saying the country can afford the hefty price tag.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PRES. BARACK OBAMA, UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: Since I took office we have cut our deficits by about two-thirds. That's the fastest period of sustained deficit reduction since after the demobilization at the end of World War II. So we can afford to make these invests while remaining fiscally responsible.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

FRANCIS: It's interesting considering the White House expects it to add nearly $6 trillion to the national debt over the next decade.

Let's bring in today's panel. James Freeman of -- from the "Wall Street Journal". Todd Starnes is from Fox News Radio. John Lonski is here as well from Moody's. You're their chief economist. All you take the crack out of it. Can we afford this -- no problem?

JOHN LONSKI, MOODY'S CHIEF ECONOMIST: Well, maybe you can afford it today but if you look forward at the funding demands from the retirement of a -- forthcoming retirement of Baby Boomers, a pressure being placed on Medicare along with us, the unknown costs of the Affordable Care Act -- never mind the possibility of another recession -- no, you cannot afford it longer term.

FRANCIS: James, I don't even think we can afford it today.

JAMES FREEMAN, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL ASSISTANT EDITOR: Yeah. And just to be clear, the -- this White House math you need to translate a little. When he's saying.

FRANCIS: Yes, please.

FREEMAN: . we've done a great job.

FRANCIS: Yes, please.

FREEMAN: . of deficit reduction, historic, what he leaves out that first year of '09 with the stimulus was highest deficit since World War II. So the fact that he gave.

FRANCIS: He's using that as base..

FREEMAN: Right. He gave us four straight years of trillion plus deficits. And now that it's gone down to 500,000 million.

FRANCIS: Right.

FREEMAN: . in any other time.

FRANCIS: Would be horrible?

FREEMAN: . would be considered horrible and irresponsible.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

FREEMAN: . he is taking credit for the reduction. But no entitlement reform in this budget.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

FREEMAN: So when we talk about future problems, no effort to fix them along with all the spending.

FRANCIS: No. And, Todd, you know, he's talking about taxing U.S. companies on overseas profits saying they should be paying their fair share. I love it when we say things like that. We're one of only countries in the world that wants to do something like this -- tax companies on their overseas profits. So it's basically unheard of around the globe.

TODD STARNES, FOX NEWS & COMMENTARY HOST: That's right. And you'll hear this president also say that he wants to look after the middle class. Well, middle class incomes under this president have gone down $4,000 annually. This is a very, very troubling time for American families.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

STARNES: And quite frankly, I don't any anybody is looking out for the working man in America.

FRANCIS: Yeah. Meanwhile, "Ale to the chief", NBC asking the really tough questions during the Super Bowl interview with President Obama.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

OBAMA: We make beer -- first president since George Washington to make some booze in the White House. Let's taste it.

SAVANNAH GUTHRIE, NBC NEWS ANCHOR: Right. Well, I'll let.

OBAMA: It's been well-reviewed.

GUTHRIE: . football or basketball?

OBAMA: I'm still a basketball guy but I love football.

GUTHRIE: Offense or defense?

OBAMA: Always offense.

GUTHRIE: Wings or chips and guac?

OBAMA: Now, that's tough. You know, I'm going chips and guac. I'm a fanatic about guac.

GUTHRIE: Hillary Clinton or Joe Biden?

OBAMA: Love them both.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

STARNES: Oh, Geezle (ph).

FRANCIS: Wow. I mean it makes GloZell look hard-hitting. Right? I mean doesn't it make you hunger for the green lipstick again? I mean, she really -- wow. Yeah. Impressed, Todd?

STARNES: OK. For the record here, let's do some history. And the president seems to thinks we still have 57 states. President Washington did not live in.

FRANCIS: Right.

STARNES: . the White House. So Mr. President, let's do some history there -- history research. Here is the issue I have. Aside from the fact that you're right, GloZell asked a more hard-hitting questions than Savannah Guthrie did, the bigger issue here is the president and the image he conveys here. He is hoisting and zipping a glass of organic honey ale.

FRANCIS: Yes.

STARNES: . with pinky finger extended.

FREEMAN: Yeah.

STARNES: What kind of message does that send our enemies?

FRANCIS: James, don't you do that?

FREEMAN: Not.

FRANCIS: No?

FREEMAN: . well, you just kind of knew it was going to be a pumpkin or honey flavored ale.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

FREEMAN: . but the.

FRANCIS: You should have that feeling.

FREEMAN: .. talking about broadcast history, back when Fox had the game last year, you had O'Reilly asking about the IRS.

FRANCIS: Right.

FREEMAN: . asking him about the rollout of the health care website. So, yeah.

FRANCIS: Not.

FREEMAN: . big contrast in the journalistic coverage.

FRANCIS: Not guac versus wings? You don't think that is presidential, John?

LONSKI: This is a great example of not wasting your time watching pre-game shows.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

LONSKI: . it's a perfect example of it.

FRANCIS: Yeah. Absolutely.

STARNES: Can I ask you this though?

FRANCIS: Yeah.

STARNES: Did anyone else notice that Savannah Guthrie, the female anchor - - they decided to do interview in a kitchen? I mean what sort of optics does send this whole war on women?

FRANCIS: There you go. I love it. All right. And ratings record for the Super Bowl -- not that interview, but for the Super Bowl itself. The dramatic finish helping the event score the highest overnight rating in history -- up 4 percent from last year. So if you leaped through that interview at beginning -- and I got to tell you I didn't even watch it, I watched parts of it later all I could stomach -- but the game was phenomenal. James. What did you think?

FREEMAN: Yeah.

FRANCIS: You loved the game?

FREEMAN: Until the end.

FRANCIS: I saw you in the hallway. You looked a little bitter.

FREEMAN: Absolutely. And I'm still bitter. I.

FRANCIS: I feel like you're a Seahawks guy.

FREEMAN: . this is a team -- this is basically the greatest team in the last 15 years, now, caught twice breaking the rules. And you could argue about.

FRANCIS: Come on.

FREEMAN: . intent. You can argue about who was it? Was it the equipment guy or whatever? But I don't think that's.

FRANCIS: The lone wolf ball boy in the bathroom.

STARNES: By the way.

FRANCIS: Yes.

STARNES: . on plus side, did you see.

FRANCIS: Yes.

STARNES: . Katy Perry straddling the mechanical lion there? Did you catch the nuance on field? She was parading through a field of inflated balls.

FRANCIS: Wow. John Lonski.

STARNES: I don't know what that means.

FRANCIS: . you want to come out and try to top that joke?

LONSKI: Well, I can't top that one but you have to admit, the Patriots denied everything -- any wrongdoing. They had no knowledge of it.

FRANCIS: Yes. So you're counting them a break. You think that -- and you're totally ignoring inflated balls coming?

LONSKI: The eye of the tiger.

FREEMAN: No one disputes the inflation of the balls were.

FRANCIS: Right. All right.

STARNES: Either fireworks otherwise.

FRANCIS: Let's do something serious here. Oil staging a rally, currently up for the third day in a row. That is shockingly crude's longest winning streak more than five months. John, I feel you'll be on solid ground with this one -- for oil.

LONSKI: Yeah. Production.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

LONSKI: . production are showing their.

FRANCIS: There you go.

LONSKI: . back on prices. You've really cut back on rig count in the United States -- down 20 percent to 30 percent. Capital spending by oil companies is dropping.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

LONSKI: So it follows that oil prices begin to move higher.

FRANCIS: A lot of people talking about these strikes that are going on at refineries around the country. And that -- I mean it's surprising to see crude rally in the face of that because normally, it would mean there'd be less demand for crude oil. So crude would fall, if refineries are on strike. It could be bad news for consumers, right, James.

FREEMAN: Yeah. I think John is solid on every topic for the record.

FRANCIS: Yes. That's right. Yes.

FREEMAN: But we, you know, we could see price rises here. You would talk about some reduction in drilling in North America. And of course if strikes threaten production, that's going to make the price go up.

FRANCIS: OK. This is a big story. Tale of two groundhogs today. Punxsutawney Phil seeing a shadow this morning seeing six more weeks of winter. But the groundhog of record in my book is Staten Island Chuck, he is predicting the end of winter. Although, we don't know who that really is because of course Mayor de Blasio killed Staten Island Chuck last year when he dropped him on his head. It turns out that wasn't even Staten Island Chuck, it was his sister Charlotte that, you know, capped last year in the middle of this whole thing.

And here we go. We're going to see it. This is where he killed it. So the groundhog died later that night. So the new replacement this year was safely in a glass box to make sure that it didn't get killed by the mayor which was really smart move. I would hide in a glass box as well.

STARNES: Now, my groundhog is General Beauregard Lee in the Southern States of Atlanta.

FRANCIS: I'm sorry, who?

STARNES: General Beauregard Lee. Are you not familiar with this?

FRANCIS: No.

STARNES: Everybody below the Mason-Dixon Line.

FRANCIS: OK.

STARNES: . looks to General Lee to determine weather. And he sided with Staten Island Chuck there.

FRANCIS: Really?

STARNES: So you got the Yankees and the southerners.

FRANCIS: You think it is over?

STARNES: I think so.

FRANCIS: Is he afraid of Mayor de Blasio? Does he know about the murder that happened last year?

STARNES: I think he does but, you know, as -- the ground hogs are known as yellow-bellied marmots, not biblical sense of the word but that's what they're officially called. And.

FRANCIS: Are you just making this up?

STARNES: No, I'm not making this up, Melissa.

FRANCIS: You're just making this up?

STARNES: Melissa, I am not making this up.

FRANCIS: Who is this guy? What? Do you want to try to weigh in there?

FREEMAN: Well, I would just say Phil has never been afraid to go against the grain on his picks.

FRANCIS: That's true.

FREEMAN: So I like it when he's out there with a bold call.

FRANCIS: Yeah.

FREEMAN: I think you're right.

FRANCIS: Which yellow-belly marmot are you on the side of, John?

LONSKI: Traditionalists. Punxsutawney Phil without a doubt. But I'm still confused.

FRANCIS: I'm completely.

LONSKI: Does he see a shadow or doesn't see a shadow?

FRANCIS: . confused. I don't know. Everything Todd said confused me. And I love it. All right. Thanks, guys. Better grab those shovels.

STARNES: I'm honored.

FRANCIS: More snow is on the way, just in time to ruin your Monday.

Plus, getting under your skin, the new technology that is opening doors for workers. More "Money" coming up.

FRANCIS: Nothing snaps you out of Super Bowl haze like being stuck in an airport in middle of a snowstorm. Wicked weather across the northeast leaving thousands of travelers stranded. Fox News' Rick Leventhal in LaGuardia Airport, New York. But first, let's go to Fox Business' Jeff Flock. He is all bundled up in Indiana. Jeff.

JEFF FLOCK, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: I get all the good time stuff, Melissa. Snow -- big snow -- last time I talked to you, maybe it was the cold, although it's not so warm now. We had blizzard conditions across much of the Midwest over the weekend. And you can see what it has brought. Take a look at all the snow out here.

Chicago had its largest -- fifth largest snowfall in a 24-hour period in this recorded history. And this is the Lake Michigan lakefront out here. Maybe, you see it. It looks a little bit more like Alaska. A lot of snow fell.

Fortunately, it has just now, within the last two hours moved off the lake effect snow that we had out here. And it is now back to, well, almost a little bit of sun peeking through. But a lot of snow left. About 18 inches in Chicago alone -- a lot of drifts, even higher than that. Good times in the Midwest, Melissa.

FRANCIS: All right. Thank you so much. Rick, how does it look at the airport?

RICK LEVENTHAL, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: It's pretty crowded with people trying to find assistance. These lines behind us are not for flight. They're for customer assistance for American Airlines. LaGuardia among the worst nationwide with 604 flights canceled today alone that were scheduled in or out. The number nationwide, much larger -- 3500 coast to coast. And if you add in yesterday and tomorrow, it's more than 5,000 flights.

We could show you the board here. You see a lot of red up there -- all those canceled flights. Those are arrivals. So if they don't arrive they can't load them up to send them back out again.

Newark is also bad. Almost 600 flights canceled there. JFK, 140 flights canceled in or out. And the weather outside is pretty bad. It's snowing. There's been a mix of sleet and freezing rain all day. And the conditions are expected to stay bad through tonight.

And of course, this ripple effect is extending across the country including to Arizona where some 80,000 people were trying to get home from the Super Bowl. That's double the normal traffic at Sky Harbor International making it the busiest day at that airport ever. Hundreds of flights canceled or delayed last night. It's a bit better today -- 27 cancellations, 38 delays.

But, Melissa, there are worst places to be stuck in Phoenix, where it's 74 and sunny today. Again, it's snowing pretty hard in New York. And it should be bad through tonight. Cancellations and delays are going to continue at least through tomorrow.

FRANCIS: Rick Leventhal, thank you so much. Thanks to both of you. Get back inside, Jeff. Go back inside. Poor guy.

All right. ExxonMobil leading energy stocks higher today. Let's go to Nicole Petallides on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange for more on that one. Nicole.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: That's right, Melissa. Tell Jeff not to freeze any longer than he needs to. Right now, we're looking at oil at $49.23. So oil is gaining for the third day in a row. We haven't seen that since August. And with that energy shares are doing quite well, Melissa. LONSKI: You've got to be careful not to over regulate the economy because the reality today is that these young people will be facing every increasing competition from the skilled and always cheaper workforce of emerging market countries.

FRANCIS: Yeah. And I mean if you look at this as a parent who has no control over those kind of things other than your vote which you have -- but it can be so frustrating to watch our politicians screw things up -- what my takeaway from this is I got to stir my kids towards the jobs where they can actually make money more than ever. You know, look out in the future and -- they got to learn to code and they've got to get out there and do the things that are going to help them because kids are falling behind right?

FREEMAN: Well, you want skills that can give them a lot of options. But I think the problem right now it's policy and yes, part of it is K-12 education. But the big part is we're not seeing business creation because we don't have an environment that lets people grow without taxation and regulation. And that really is a -- it's the irony of the Obama era. All the people that he talks about helping.

FRANCIS: Right.

FREEMAN: . have had terrible time since he was elected.

FRANCIS: Right, John? Yeah.

LONSKI: He's exactly right. That's a sad story because it's actually the lower classes that have feared the worst over the last eight years or so.

FRANCIS: Yeah. Absolutely. All right, gentlemen. Thanks to both of you. I wanted to show you something fun before we go. Bruce Turkel sent this to me when we were doing our Super Bowl segment. Take a look that. That's Katy Perry in her costume from last night. Right next to her that's Will Ferrell from "Blades of Glory".

I think Katy may have borrowed the costume. What do you think, James?

FREEMAN: Yeah. It's a classic. I mean not quite on the level (inaudible) but it certainly.

FRANCIS: That's right.

FREEMAN: . a nommage at the Super Bowl.

FRANCIS: Fabulous. I know. John, you want to get in there?

LONSKI: In this side of economy, you got to be much more creative. (inaudible)

FRANCIS: I love it. Pretty facts. Economics no matter what. My head is off to you, John Lonski. Thank you. That's all the money we have for you. Here's Liz.
