Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RGB-27W1-F021-6418-00000-00'Never get high on your own supply' - why social media bosses don't use social media;Developers of platforms such as Facebook have admitted that they were designed to be addictive. Should we be following the executives' example and going cold turkey - and is it even possible for mere mortals?2018-01-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:44ZLexisNexisMEDIAVersion:1'Never get high on your own supply' - why social media bosses don't use social mediaDevelopers of platforms such as Facebook have admitted that they were designed to be addictive. Should we be following the executives' example and going cold turkey - and is it even possible for mere mortals?Alex Hern

Mark Zuckerberg doesn't use Facebook like you or me. The 33-year-old chief executive has a team of 12 moderators dedicated to deleting comments and spam from his page, according to Bloomberg. He has a "handful" of employees who help him write his posts and speeches and a number of professional photographers who take perfectly stage-managed pictures of him meeting veterans in Kentucky, small-business owners in Missouri or cheesesteak vendors in Philadelphia.

Facebook's locked-down nature means mere mortals can't see the private posts on Zuckerberg's timeline, but it is hard to imagine him getting into arguments about a racist relative's post of an anti-immigration meme. And it is not just Zuckerberg. None of the company's key executives has a "normal" Facebook presence. You can't add them as friends, they rarely post publicly and they keep private some information that the platform suggests be made public by default, such as the number of friends they have.

Over at Twitter, the story is the same. Of the company's nine most senior executives, only four tweet more than once a day on average. Ned Segal, its chief financial officer, has been on the site for more than six years and has sent fewer than two tweets a month. Co-founder Jack Dorsey, a relatively prolific tweeter, has sent about 23,000 since the site was launched, but that is a lot less than even halfway engaged users have sent over the same period. Dorsey rarely replies to strangers and avoids discussions or arguments on the site. He doesn't live-tweet TV shows or sporting fixtures. In fact, he does not really "use" Twitter; he just posts on it occasionally.

Related: I was Mark Zuckerberg's mentor. Today I would tell him: your users are in peril

It is a pattern that holds true across the sector. For all the industry's focus on "eating your own dog food", the most diehard users of social media are rarely those sitting in a position of power.

I am a compulsive social media user. I have sent about 140,000 tweets since I joined Twitter in April 2007 - six Jacks' worth. I use Instagram, Snapchat and Reddit daily. I have accounts on Ello, Peach and Mastodon (remember them? No? Don't worry). Three years ago, I managed to quit Facebook. I went cold turkey, deleting my account in a moment of lucidity about how it made me feel and act. I have never regretted it, but I haven't been able to pull the same stunt twice.

I used to look at the heads of the social networks and get annoyed that they didn't understand their own sites. Regular users encounter bugs, abuse or bad design decisions that the executives could never understand without using the sites themselves. How, I would wonder, could they build the best service possible if they didn't use their networks like normal people?

Now, I wonder something else: what do they know that we don't?

Sean Parker, the founding president of Facebook, broke the omerta in October last year, telling a conference in Philadelphia that he was "something of a conscientious objector" to social media.

"The thought process that went into building these applications, Facebook being the first of them ... was all about: 'How do we consume as much of your time and conscious attention as possible?' That means that we need to sort of give you a little dopamine hit every once in a while, because someone liked or commented on a photo or a post or whatever. And that's going to get you to contribute more content and that's going to get you ... more likes and comments," he said.

The short-term, dopamine-driven feedback loops that we have created are destroying how society works

Former Facebook executive Chamath Palihapitiya

"It's a social-validation feedback loop ... exactly the kind of thing that a hacker like myself would come up with, because you're exploiting a vulnerability in human psychology. The inventors, creators - me, Mark [Zuckerberg], Kevin Systrom on Instagram, all of these people - understood this consciously. And we did it anyway."

A month later, Parker was joined by another Facebook objector, former vice-president for user growth Chamath Palihapitiya. "The short-term, dopamine-driven feedback loops that we have created are destroying how society works. No civil discourse, no cooperation; misinformation, mistruth," Palihapitiya said at a conference in Stanford, California. "This is not about Russian ads. This is a global problem. It is eroding the core foundations of how people behave by and between each other. I can control my decision, which is that I don't use that shit. I can control my kids' decisions, which is that they're not allowed to use that shit."

Palihapitiya's statements rattled Facebook so much that the company issued a response acknowledging its past failings - a rare move for a business that, despite its mission to "connect people", is notoriously taciturn about its shortcomings. "When Chamath was at Facebook, we were focused on building new social media experiences and growing Facebook around the world," a company spokeswoman said. "Facebook was a very different company back then... as we have grown, we have realised how our responsibilities have grown, too. We take our role very seriously and we are working hard to improve."

A few days later, the site pulled a more interesting move, releasing the results of research that suggested that Facebook did make users feel bad - but only if they didn't post enough. "In general, when people spend a lot of time passively consuming information - reading, but not interacting with people - they report feeling worse afterward," two Facebook researchers said in a review of the existing literature. On the other hand, "actively interacting with people - especially sharing messages, posts and comments with close friends and reminiscing about past interactions - is linked to improvements in wellbeing". How convenient.

For Adam Alter, a psychologist and the author of Irresistible, an examination of technology addiction, it is almost besides the point whether social media makes you happy or sad in the short term. The deeper issue is that your usage is compulsive - or even addictive.

"The addiction concept applies much more broadly and to many more behaviours than we perhaps thought and also therefore applies to many more people in the population," Alter says. "Roughly half the adult population has at least one behavioural addiction. Not many of us have substance addictions, but the way the world works today there are many, many behaviours that are hard for us to resist and a lot of us develop self-undermining attachments to those behaviours that border on or become addictions."

These addictions haven't happened accidentally, Alter argues. Instead, they are a direct result of the intention of companies such as Facebook and Twitter to build "sticky" products, ones that we want to come back to over and over again. "The companies that are producing these products, the very large tech companies in particular, are producing them with the intent to hook. They're doing their very best to ensure not that our wellbeing is preserved, but also that we spend as much time on their products and on their programs and apps as possible. That's their key goal: it's not to make a product that people enjoy and therefore becomes profitable, but rather to make a product that people can't stop using and therefore becomes profitable.

"What Parker and Palihapitiya are saying is that these companies, companies that they've been exposed to at the highest levels and from very early on, have been founded on these principles - that we should do everything we possibly can to hack human psychology, to understand what it is that keeps humans engaged and to use those techniques not to maximise wellbeing, but to maximise engagement. And that's explicitly what they do."

Parker and Palihapitiya aren't the only Silicon Valley residents to open up about their unease with the habit-forming nature of modern technology. As the Guardian reported in October, a growing number of coders and designers are quitting their jobs in disillusionment at what their work entails. From Chris Marcellino - one of the inventors of Apple's system for push notifications, who quit the industry to train as a neurosurgeon - to Loren Britcher - who created the pull-to-refresh motion that turns so many apps into miniature one-armed-bandits and is now devoting his time to building a house in New Jersey - many of the workers at the coalface of interface design have had second thoughts.

Others have had the same realisation, but have decided to embrace the awkwardness - such as LA-based retention consultants Dopamine Labs. The company offers a plugin service that personalises "moments of joy" in apps that use it. It promises customers : "Your users will crave it. And they'll crave you."

If this is the case, then social media executives are simply following the rule of pushers and dealers everywhere, the fourth of the Notorious BIG's Ten Crack Commandments: "Never get high on your own supply."

"Many tech titans are very, very careful about how they privately use tech and how they allow their kids to use it and the extent to which they allow their kids access to screens and various apps and programs," says Alter. "They will get up on stage, some of them, and say things like: 'This is the greatest product of all time,' but then when you delve you see they don't allow their kids access to that same product."

Tech by itself doesn't want to be good... It takes humans to make sure that the things that you do with it are good

Apple chief executive Tim Cook

Last week, Apple's chief executive, Tim Cook, told the Guardian : "I don't have a kid, but I have a nephew that I put some boundaries on. There are some things that I won't allow. I don't want them on a social network."

He added: "Technology by itself doesn't want to be good and it doesn't want to be bad either. It takes humans to make sure that the things that you do with it are good. And it takes humans in the development process to make sure the creation of the product is a good thing."

Alter says that the classic example of this approach is Cook's predecessor, Steve Jobs, "who spoke about all the virtues of the iPad and then wouldn't let his kids near it". ("They haven't used it," Jobs told a New York Times reporter a few months after the iPad was released. "We limit how much technology our kids use at home.")

It is not only children. "You can see it in their own behaviour," Alter says. "Jack Dorsey, the way he uses Twitter, it seems he's very careful about how much time he spends. He's obviously a very busy guy and a very high-functioning guy, but as a result he's probably distracted by a lot of other things and he's able to tear himself away from the platform.

"But that's not true for all of the users of Twitter - many of them report being, using the colloquial term, addicted. Whether or not that's clinical addiction, it feels to them like they would like to be doing less; it's undermining their wellbeing. And I think that's absolutely right: for many Twitter users, it's sort of a black hole that sucks you in and it's very hard to stop using the program."

That is certainly how I feel about Twitter. I have tried to cut back, after realising how much of my time was spent staring at a scrolling feed of aphorisms ranging from mildly amusing to vaguely traumatic. I deleted 133,000 tweets, in an effort to reduce the feeling that I couldn't give up on something into which I had sunk so much time. I removed the apps from my phone and my computer, forcing any interaction through the web browser. I have taken repeated breaks. But I keep coming back.

It is one thing to be a child with a protective parent keeping technology away from you. It is quite another to live like a technology executive yourself, defeating the combined effort of thousands of the world's smartest people to instil a craving to open their app every day. I am not alone in struggling.

Related: How big tech finally awakened to the horror of its own inventions

Kevin Holesh, a freelance app developer, is one of those who tried to cut back. He wrote a program, Moment, that tracks how long you spend looking at your phone each day. For the average user, it is more than three hours every day. Holesh's stats were enough to provide the motivation for change. "Once I had the hard data, that itself was helping me use my phone less. I've taken a few steps in that direction since, but I knew just seeing the number itself was half the battle. Seeing that number really changed my approach ... I was spending an hour a day not doing anything productive, just wasting time."

Holesh eventually removed all social networks, and his work email account, from his phone. "That's the step that helps me the most, simply not having it accessible. At first, my mission was just: find out what amount of phone time makes you happy. But now I've started a little more extreme approach, I'm less stressed out about news articles or my uncle posting something inflammatory on Facebook. I find I do a better job of communicating in more old-fashioned methods."

Alter says willpower can help to a certain extent, while leaving things out of reach for casual, thoughtless use can help more. Ultimately, however, addictions are hard to break alone.

"It's possible that in 20 years we'll look back at the current generation of children and say: 'Look, they are socially different from every other generation of humans that came before and as a result this is a huge problem and maybe we need to regulate these behaviours.' Or perhaps we'll look back and say: 'I don't know what the fuss was - I'm not sure why we were so concerned.' Until we have some evidence, until there's something that seems tangible, I think it's going to be very hard to get people en masse to change how they behave."

If you can't bring yourself to cut back on social media, you could try following Zuckerberg's example and hire a team of 12 to do it for you. It might not be as cheap and easy as deleting Facebook, but it is probably easier to stick to.

urn:contentItem:5X16-9NW1-F0HT-S12F-00000-00New 5G portfolio launched for investors in Asia2019-09-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:44ZLexisNexisNew 5G portfolio launched for investors in AsiaAnnabelle Liang

The portfolio consists of 45 companies involved in 5G infrastructure or technology development

Multi-asset trading platform eToro has launched a fifth generation (5G) portfolio for Asian investors wanting a stake in the up-and-coming sector.

The 5G Revolution portfolio consists of 45 companies involved in related infrastructure or technology development.

Toby Wu, senior analyst at eToro, told Citywire Asia that it is suitable for anyone looking for exposure to the 5G space, including HNW investors. The minimum buy-in is $2,000. 

The portfolio features Asian-based companies such as China's ZTE Corporation, which was once banned by the US for breaching the terms of a business deal. The ban was lifted last July and ZTE's revenue has since recovered. 

China Unicom (Hong Kong), China Mobile, China Telecommunications Corporation and Lenovo Group were also included.

Wu said the inclusion of Chinese companies 'fits well with China's move to open up its telecommunications industry.' He added that the portfolio will be periodically rebalanced as different companies enter the space. 

The new portfolio also features non-Asian companies, such as American Tower Corporation, which has leased space for the building of antennas and wireless equipment.

It also includes network providers Deutsche Telekom, Vodafone and Verizon, semiconductor manufacturers Micron Technology and Broadcom, and infrastructure giants Ericsson, Intel and Qualcomm. 

5G, which is set to be rolled out in many countries by the early 2020s, is seen as a big opportunity for investors, said Yoni Assia, CEO and co-founder of eToro.

It will offer wireless speeds that are up to 100 times faster than current 4G technology. The 5G market, which was valued at $34 billion in 2017, is expected to balloon to $3.4 trillion by 2026. 

'That said, it’s not a straightforward sector to invest in. Each country’s approach to 5G will be different and there are several regulatory, legal and planning hurdles to a successful rollout. 

'We’ve selected companies in this sector that have the potential to offer a strong investment case for years to come,' Assia added.

eToro has launched other thematic portfolios providing exposure to big tech, crypto assets, genome engineering and cannabis industries, among others. It launched a drone portfolio for global retail investors in July.

That is not what a Republic is about because only favored people get to do the dealing. So I don't like partnership. I want an environment where people can be competitive and produce things that are necessary. But saying ...

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5NSR-DNJ1-DY0W-435D-00000-00New Agenda Push; Outrage In The Park; Jeff Immelt Stepping Down; Penguins Win Stanley Cup; Flier-In-Chief; President Trump Travel Ban Push;2017-06-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:44ZLexisNexisNew Agenda Push; Outrage In The Park; Jeff Immelt Stepping Down; Penguins Win Stanley Cup; Flier-In-Chief; President Trump Travel Ban Push;LanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, June 12th. Your top stories at 8:00 a.m. Eastern Time. Getting the agenda back on track, President Trump expected to unveil a new jobs push in Wisconsin, tomorrow. The move comes as the White House moves past the controversy surrounding Jim Comey's testimony last week. First Daughter, Ivanka Trump, was asked on "FOX & FRIENDS" earlier about her father's response to that controversy.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

IVANKA TRUMP, DAUGHTER OF PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP: My father felt very vindicated in all the statements that he has been making and feels incredibly optimistic but, you know, at the White House and throughout the administration we were incredibly focused on the reason we all went to Washington.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Sure.

TRUMP: And what we're fighting for. So last week, while it didn't get the level of headlines, it will ultimately have a much more important impact, it was infrastructure week, focusing on the commitment to rebuild this country.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: More from Ivanka Trump's interview ahead. Outrage in Central Park, a New York City play using a President Trump look-alike for the role of the assassinated Julius Caesar. The fallout as both Delta and Bank of America pulled their sponsorships.

Breaking news this morning, Jeff Immelt out at General Electric. The company announcing earlier this morning that he will be replaced by John Flannery as chairman and CEO. Flannery, the current president and CEO of G.E. Healthcare. G.E. shares up three percent on the news, that stock down this year, down in the last year, and down about 28 percent during Immelt's tenure since 2001.

Futures are showing losses across the board, 34-point loss on the Dow Futures, we keep a very close eye on what happens with technology stocks. These big names, your Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, Google, Apple, and Microsoft had been your major market leaders, pulling the rest of the market along all year and they took a beating on Friday and many of them lower in premarket trading.

In Europe, stocks also heading south, we have a one percent loss in France and in Germany. Same story in Asia overnight, you have red across your screen with the biggest loser there being the Hang Seng, down one and a quarter percent.

And the Penguins putting the Predators on ice. Pittsburgh topping Nashville to win its second straight Stanley Cup. The highlights from that big win ahead. Plus, Jimmy Carter, the president - former president taking flight, the former leader of the free world, a video of him going viral after he took the time to great everyone on his plane. The presidential surprise for passengers, the surprise being Mr. Carter was flying commercial. There you go. All of that -- cancer survivor, by the way, as well, all of that and so much more coming up.

Financial analyst, Heather Zumarraga, Rhino Trading Partners Chief Strategist, Michael Block, and PwC Partner, Mitch Roschelle. Good to see you, one and all, this morning.

HEATHER ZUMARRAGA, SUNAMERICA FUNDS VICE PRESIDENT: Good morning.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: What's on your mind? Immelt out.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PWC PARTNER & BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT LEADER: I'm interested to see what happens with those big tech names because if they start to continue to sell off, they're so heavy in the indices, that it could start dragging the market down and start getting everybody worried that Trump rally is a thing of the past.

ZUMARRAGA: Dated. NASDAQ down 1.8 percent on Friday. We'll see if we get some follow through today to see if there's a sector rotation, as the NASDAQ is pulling back, the Dow has been hitting new all-time highs.

MCDOWELL: And the Russell 2000, the small-cap stocks (INAUDIBLE) a record on Friday.

(CROSSTALK)

ROSCHELLE: That's a good story though.

MICHAEL BLOCK, RHINO TRADING PARTNERS CHIEF STRATEGIST: The Russell caught up too. Yes.

ZUMARRAGA: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

BLOCK: Russell caught up because everyone was shorted?

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: Sector rotation.

BLOCK: No, no. It's squeezing. Full state of rotation continues.

ROSCHELLE: And the Fed is hiking this week.

ZUMARRAGA: Yes. Very important.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: No. I mean, take that one to the bank I think what Jon Hilsenrath would have done.

(CROSSTALK)

ROSCHELLE: -- got lost in the headlines when you never know what happens with Sessions' testimony. So .

MCDOWELL: We'll keep it in the headlines right here on Fox Business as we always do.

ROSCHELLE: There you go.

MCDOWELL: We can talk about everything. Joining the conversation this morning, former Texas Congressman Presidential Candidate, Ron Paul, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY", Mr. Stuart Varney. We always love to see Mr. Varney. To our story this hour, today is the deadline for parties challenging the president's travel ban to respond to a petition from justice department.

The petition asks the Supreme Court to allow the president's executive order to go into effect. Despite opposition, Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton says the president has the right to enact this ban. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KEN PAXTON, TEXAS ATTORNEY GENERAL: We think we're absolutely right on the law, there's a federal law that clearly gives the president the authority to do this. This travel ban is right in line with that statute. And so, we're confident if the court actually follows federal law, that the president will be just fine.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Joining me now is the co-founder of Diligence LLC, former CIA Operative Mike Baker. I don't even know where you are but I know you parachuted in or tunneled in.

MIKE BAKER, FORMER CIA OPERATIVE: He can't tell you where he is. I'm at the - I'm at the compound right now. It's a secret - it's a secret location except I got a picture of it behind me.

MCDOWELL: This is why you have to - this is why you have to follow Mike on Twitter because it's always like he's on a - like a gator boat, like a fan boat coming in.

BAKER: Get in your boat --

MCDOWELL: Mike, is these bans a significant step in focusing on national security?

BAKER: Well, you know, it's become this outsized thing that is chewing up a lot of political capital and a lot of - a lot of attention and it really didn't need to, it's important and it - and it should be done, and the previous administration, you know, the Obama administration had identified and outlined the same problem but because of the messaging issues, the discipline coming out of the White House in this current administration, it's unfortunately - it's taken on this concept that somehow the travel ban is critical for national security. Well, it's an element of national security.

It is a very simple process, you've got these states, these nations that are essentially failed states. And the previous administration agreed and the idea being is, well, let's take a break, let's review internally our processes for how we -- how we do a the vetting, how we do the due diligence, the background checking on people who want to come to this country from these particular failed states, where there's no infrastructure, there's no ability to reach in and in a logical and efficient manner, check databases and talk to people to understand who are these people that want to come in.

It's s simply that and then once you do that, fine, improve your systems and the suspension is over. But that's not the way it works, so it's become this thing that like I said is just chewing up a tremendous amount of political capital.

MCDOWELL: At the same time that you have this new developing diplomatic crisis in the Middle East with Qatar, now hiring Former Attorney General John Ashcroft in response to accusation that the nation supports terror groups in the region. Saudi Arabia and several other Gulf nations cut diplomatic ties with Qatar last week over the terror allegations, Egyptian billionaire businessman Naguib Sawiris backing the decision on Wall Street Week when he talked to Maria on Friday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK MORNINGS WITH MARIA HOST: Tell us why you're advising your colleagues in business to take their money out of Qatar right now?

NAGUIB SAWIRIS, EGYPTIAN BILLIONAIRE BUSINESSMAN: Well, I'm not just advising them to take their money out to Qatar, I'm advising them not to deal with Qatar, point, you know, because we are all watching every day, we wake up hearing a lunatic that - or a savage person that went -- goes with the car and kills innocent people or like in my own country here, they stop the bus with children and women and shot the - shot the men in front of the eyes of the women and every day we hear all these incidents, you know.

And nobody is doing anything against it and we need to come to the bottom of that and the -- one country that declares openly that it is supporting terror, you know, like Hamas or other organizations that's siding with Iran openly that all intelligence services of the world have all materials showing that they're supporting all the terrorists and extremist groups in Middle East from Libya, in Syria, in Iraq and everywhere.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Mike, what is this rift in Qatar mean for us because again, this comes on the heels of Obama-backed and brokered Iranian nuclear deal.

BAKER: Yes. And then - and, you know, that sound bite there, gave away the sort of the reason why this has exploded into an issue, and it's Iran. So this is essentially at the top line, a conflict between the Saudis and Iran, and the Saudis, Iran obviously has their Lex Luthor and, you know, they are locked in this battle for influence and in the region. So the Saudis have exerted a great deal of pressure on some of these other countries that Egypt included to isolate Qatar.

You know, the truth of the matter is that, you know, they're all complicit in different ways over different periods of time and either financing or somehow supporting or looking the other way in terms of Islamic extremism. So Qatar doesn't stand alone in that and what needs to happen and what's going to be extremely difficult is, you know, the U.S. in particular, we're going to need to find a way to step into that breach and bring them back together in a fashion because we're not going to - we're not going to do this, we're not going to beat terrorism by isolating Qatar.

You know, we've got a military base there, and different things can be true at the same time in Middle East. You can be working with a partner out there who on one hand, at a one side of their mouth helps you with certain terrorist operations or providing intelligence, to us and our liaise on partners, at the same time there can be elements within that government that sympathize or support terrorism or business that do same thing. You got, you know, you got to deal with, you know, the world is that exists and not try to find some perfect ending.

ROSCHELLE: And Mike, Mitch Roschelle, with all those Sunni-Shia conflict that's going on, doesn't Iran just need trading partners and maybe they were looking to make a friend in Qatar because there's so many players in the region that just will trade with them and they need trading partners?

BAKER: Well, sure, they like as many trading partners as possible but, you know, over the top of that is the fact that Iran is doing it for the regime's best interest which is to drive a wedge between these countries and to try to degree possible to pull them out of the Saudi sphere. Again, this is - this is a Saudi-Iranian dispute. I wouldn't ascribe any sort of innocent economic reasoning behind anything that the Iranian regime does.

So I think - I think your take on it, while there is an element of economic truth there, the reality is it's more nefarious than that.

BLOCK: Mike, what's the - what's the endgame for Qatar here? Because they've been very Machiavellian I would say, they play from both sides, they're friends with everybody that have Al-Jazeera, you know (INAUDIBLE) they deal with Iran, they were dealing with the west - we have the big base there, you know, it sounds like probably they're getting called on playing both sides here. How does this end for them? Is there something that taunts where that continues or is the line drawn and they have to choose a side or have a side chosen for them?

BAKER: No. I don't think it's going to be a hardline decision at the end where they, you know, that's it, there's a final break from, you know, from the -- sort of this traditional alliance where, you know, to some degree they have been aligned with UAE and Egypt and the others, and Saudis. I think what will happen is -- I hope what will happen is that there will be a significant diplomatic effort led by Rex Tillerson and some others.

And at the end of the day, we'll heal the rift to some degree, they'll open the borders, there will be business but we have to be pragmatic and understand that, you know, again, there will be this duplicity that exists, so that's not just - again, it's not just Qatar. I mean, look at the Saudis in the way over the time they dealt with the devil, they've turned the other way and in terms of allowing the extremism to build in exchange for, you know, stability within the kingdom.

So, you know, the Middle East is one of those places where, you know, it's on satisfactory but you have to deal with who exists there and you have to understand it would be very, very hard line pragmatic about this to understand that they're going to be duplicities in the way that they act when it comes to extremism.

MCDOWELL: Mike, when you leave, do you ignite your jet propulsion pack since why you're sitting in the state. Why right out?

BAKER: Yes. Yes. We tend to - everything disappears, you know, it's a little bit like Mr. Wolfe, you know, you got to clean the place up and then you go and, you know, and you find another place where we can do another segment. But yes, it's - it is what it is. Look, I'm out in Idaho, I'm going to release that information to the public, I was going to give it to a friend and then you're going to hand it the press but I'm in Idaho, and anybody out there watching hasn't been to Idaho, I'm here to tell you, it's one of the greatest states in the nation.

MCDOWELL: It really is. It is stunningly beautiful but I would deeply, deeply appreciate your Winston Wolfe reference.

BAKER: Thank you. Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Mike Baker. Big love always. Mike Baker joining us.

BAKER: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Coming up. A scare in the air for flyers aboard at flight to Shanghai, a plane forced to turn around after a hole rips open in the engine. And a shake-up at the top of General Electric, Jeff Immelt out. We look at future of this company because the road since he took over in '01 was a lo rocky one.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Breaking news this morning. General Electric getting a new leader. Cheryl Casone has the details. Hey, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK FINANCIAL CONTRIBUTOR: Hey Dagen, that's right. G.E. CEO Jeff Immelt is retiring, he's ending a 16-year run as the leader of industrial conglomerate. He's going to be replaced by John Flannery in August who's currently the president and CEO of G.E. Healthcare. Now, the possible move first reported by our very ow3n Charlie Gasparino. He broke that news on the tensions between Immelt and activist investor Nelson Peltz.

That report from Charlie - excuse me, was back in March. General Electric says Immelt is going to remain chairman of the board through the end of the year. Flannery going to take on that title, January 1st. Immelt has taken steps to reship - reshape G.E. after the financial crisis for the company. They have struggled a boost profit there. As you can see, there is the stock in the premarket, it is rallying. G.E. shares are rallying up a little more than three percent. That will actually help balance out the Dow when we open up at 9:30 a.m. Eastern Time today.

Also, we're following this story for you. A huge hole in a China Eastern plane forced an emergency landing in Australia. Passengers of the flight from the city to Shanghai said the engine made a massive amount of noise right after takeoff. Pilots reported problems about an hour into the journey. The plane had to return to Sydney, it land safely. Passengers were evacuated from plane but luckily, there were no injuries there.

Well, a Trump t-shirt censored in a high school yearbook. Grant Berardo took his high school pictures in New Jersey wearing Trump campaign shirt, this is Make America Great Again but the t-shirt was later digitally altered to remove the campaign slogan in the actual yearbook. The school superintendent is investigating this, says there is no policy prohibiting political messages in schools pictures.

And then this, passengers on a recent Delta Airlines flight got a big surprise. Former President Jimmy Carter was on board and before the plane took off, he walked up and down the aisle shook hands with passengers. They were really excited. There you go. This is the tweeted video shows the 92-year-old former president smiling as he walked down the aisle. He greets everybody. The passenger tweeted the video, said, everybody seemed really excited. And the overall sense it was just really nice to have that kind of moment where party or politics "Didn't matter." One of the most -- I think revered ex-presidents we have living today, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: (INAUDIBLE) but a cancer survivor, you know, he went on one of these Immunotherapy drugs from the Kansas spread to his brain spectacular until -

CASONE: Uh-hmm. And look at him.

MCDOWELL: Spectacular --

CASONE: Yes.

MCDOWELL: -- recovery. I wish the president talked more about that actually. Thank you so much, Cheryl. Coming up. The Penguins iced the Predators to keep the cup in Pittsburg. Highlights from the repeat NHL title victory in nearly 20 years.

And bling with a zing, how to Patriots are using their Super Bowl reign to remind the Falcons off their incredible comeback in February.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: The hockey season coming to a close after an exciting Stanley Cup final between the Penguins the Predators. Jared Max is here with the highlights. Hey, Jared.

JARED MAX, FOX NEWS HEADLINES 24/7 AMERICAN SPORTS REPORTER: Hey, Dagen. I thought we were headed for sudden death overtime last night. 0-0 game until under two minutes remaining. Game six Stanley Cup final in Nashville, the Predators fans continue their tradition, throwing catfish on the ice and it looked like the Predators had reeled in the first goal of the game. Colton Sissons taps it in after Pittsburg goalie Matt Murray was unable to control Filip Forsberg's shot. 1-0 Predators, right? Wrong!

Officials had lost sight of the puck and one blew a whistle to signal the play dead, fraction of a second before the puck went in. 0-0 to the third and then the Penguins get this weird goal from behind the net, the former Predator Patric Hornqvist sneaks it past Pekka Rinne, this goal counted. Penguins 1-0, a minute later they scored through an empty net. Celebration was on a first time in era of salary cap. One team wins the Stanley Cup two straight seasons. Penguins' parade will be this week. No official date yet.

Could be preparing for another championship parade and NBA one for the Golden State Warriors soon. Warriors up three games to one and the Cavaliers favored to win tonight by 8.5 points, tip off scheduled for just after 9:00 Eastern in Oakland. We all know Air Jordans are not cheap sneakers but what about a pair of real about Michael Jordans? As in sneaks worn by the basketball legend in his final game as an amateur. Well, the sneakers that Jordan wore in the gold medal game in the '84 Olympics at Spain sold at auction yesterday for $190,373. Almost 200 grand. Yes, highest known price paid for game-worn shoes. I even had Jordans orthotics and the autograph.

Back page of the New York Post today asks the question, he hit it how far? New York Yankees star Aaron Judge, longest homerun in Major League Baseball since ESPN began tracking distance of homeruns in 2009. Watch this. Now Judge hit two homeruns in the Yankees 14-3 win over Orioles. This was his first. It traveled 4696 feet. He is first Yankees since Mickey Mantle in 1956 two hit homers in the same game, he goes four for four, first Yankees since Roger Maris, age 25 or younger to hit 20 homeruns before the all-star break. Judge has 21, he's batting 344.

Football. You know, football said to be the sport of kings, better than diamond rings but maybe not this ring. Check this out, past Friday night; New England Patriots owner Robert Craft hosted a private ceremony for his players and team members at his home. Well, they all got their championship rings. Remember that 28 to 3 comeback against the Atlanta Falcons in Super Bowl? So, 283 rings to recognize the 28 to 3 comeback. 283 diamonds are on this ring, it totals 5.1 carats. And all Tom Brady showing it off along with Martellus Bennett. So they have a 28 to 3, a little bit of a dig at the Falcons and also a couple of quotes on the rings, as well from Bob Craft, the team owner, unequivocally the sweetest and also greatest comeback all-time. How about those rings?

MCDOWELL: I can't wear them all at the same time.

BLOCK: It should have had two big diamonds on them to represent the two times they couldn't beat the Giants in Super Bowl.

ROSCHELLE: There you go.

MAX: I like that. I like that. That's fair. It's a good shot.

MCDOWELL: Dropping the mic on that one, Mike. Dropping the mic, Mike. A brain freeze attack on the baseball field video showing a young fan winning a slurpy-sipping contest and that's going viral. Let's watch that.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Six, five, four -- and time, time, all right. We are going to stop. All right. Let's see. Let's open , Kinley's. Kinley, what do you think, Rock?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MAX: Minor League Baseball (INAUDIBLE) you had to know this was going to happen.

BLOCK: We've all -

MAX: Dagen, no joke like eight years ago, I was sucking down one of those coffee (INAUDIBLE) Dunkin' Donuts, I fainted. I'm not kidding, got brain freeze and the next thing I knew I came to.

ZUMARRAGA: Are you kidding?

MAX: No. Serious thing. And then I let you know -

(CROSSTALK)

ROSCHELLE: It happened in New Orleans with the hurricane but that thing - that was (INAUDIBLE)

MAX: Yes, yes, yes. Different thing. This had no alcohol in it. But yes, the brain that - it's not fun.

MCDOWELL: I thought that video was - it shows people why you should go to Minor League Games.

MAX: Yes.

ROSCHELLE: Yes.

MCDOWELL: like I, you know, brain freeze?

ZUMARRAGA: No, but they do really fun stuff but --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: Like fun promotions and it's really about the community and local community and --

MAX: And watching baseball and not costing, you know, $400 for the family for it.

MCDOWELL: Right, exactly. And not being a major headache against the ballpark. I mean - because that is part of it. So hey, are you jealous? Are you going to U.S. Open?

MAX: I'm not. I'm not going.

MCDOWELL: So are you jealous that we're going? We're going to be -

(CROSSTALK)

MAX: I'm a little bit jealous. We can talk about that off the air.

ZUMARRAGA: I am very - now I'm very excited. I'm super excited.

MAX: Will you guys be texting me like, "Hey, what's an eagle? What's a double-eagle?

MCDOWELL: No. Ah, ah, ah, ah.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: I went to Wake Forest, as the home of Arnold Palmer, Lanny Wadkins, Curtis Strange, Billy Andrade. So I know my, Michael.

MAX: What's your handicap?

MCDOWELL: Oh, I am a horrible golfer. But I know, Michael.

MAX: Are you looking forward to? It should be gorgeous.

MCDOWELL: I love why -- there is nothing better than being on a course and watching really incredible golf because you get to see firsthand, how incredibly difficult it is.

MAX: Beautiful time of year also to be in Wisconsin. Erin Hills looks to be pretty gorgeous course.

MCDOWELL: Oh my gosh. Yes. I love the people of Wisconsin, so open your arms, people, we'll be there Thursday and Friday. Thank you, Jared.

MAX: Thanks.

MCDOWELL: Jared Max. Jared's sports report on Fox News Headlines, 24/7 SiriusXM 115. Coming up, getting the agenda back on track. President Trump preparing to meet with his cabinet as Republicans tackle healthcare and tax reform. And Microsoft (INAUDIBLE) Xbox, a first look at the video game console coming from the tech titan.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Dagen Mcdowell for Maria Bartiromo, Monday, June 12th. Top stories 8:30 a.m. Eastern time. Getting America back to work. President Trump expected to unveil a new jobs push in Wisconsin tomorrow. The announcement comes amid a new agenda push for the White House, as the administration is trying to shake off the Russia election investigation controversy. Senator Lindsey Graham warning President he needs to get out of his own way.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R), SOUTH CAROLINA: You may be the first President in history to go down because you can't stop inappropriately talking about an investigation. If you were quiet, would clear you. It is frustrating or to me to want to help a man I think will do good things no other Republican will do.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: The latest on renewed agenda push, ahead. And breaking news these mornings, Jeff Immelt out at General Electric. He will be replaced by John Flannery as Chairman and CEO. Flannery is the current President and CEO of G.E. health care. This move was not totally unexpected. And investors are showing quite a bit optimism about the future direction of General Electric under Flannery. Shares up 3.6 percent. They're way down this year, while the market has been hitting record highs down in the last year and down under Jeff Immelt's tenure as well.

Uber under fire. The Board of Directors expected to unveil a massive shake-up, following an investigation into the company sexual harassment scandal. Reports saying the CEO could take leave of absence. The details ahead.

Dow Futures helped higher by General Electric. But the NASDAQ taking a hit, NASDAQ 100 futures, are down big time. Major sell-off in technology on Friday and has some worried. These big tech stocks titans have been leading this market higher, and they've been going down, down, down the last two days.

In Europe, stocks lower across the board. Well, FTSE 100 turned around, the CAC Quarante in France and the Dax still lower. In Asia overnight, it was right across your screen losses in Japan, Hong Kong, Shanghai, and South Korea.

It could be rough for Apple. The company stock downgraded for second time in a week over concerns around iPhone 8 on 2 percent right now. It looks like unchanged but there is a major loss in Apple shares on Friday down almost four percent. There you go. Down about two percent at the moment. Why the enthusiasm might be too much.

And gamers rejoicing a system coming to town. Microsoft unveiling the X- Box X. The new features could be showing up in your living room or bedroom or wherever you play games.

President Trump making a big push for jobs this week unveiling new plans to combat the skills gap. Blake Burman at the White House with more. Good morning, Blake.

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT: Hi there, Dagen. Good morning to you as well. Last week at the White House was infrastructure week at a rollout. It got a bit muddled once Jim Comey headed to Capitol Hill. This week, they have got a new focus somewhat of a round two. They will be focusing on workforce development. The main push here according to top officials, at the White House, is on trying to build out apprenticeship to that end. The President will be headed on the road this week, tomorrow, he will be going to Wisconsin, speaking at a trade school in Waukesha, Wednesday to Labor Department, Thursday, here at the White House.

He has a roundtable with several state governors. This whole issue of workforce development has been a push of Ivanka Trump. She was on "FOX & FRIENDS" this morning to tout rollout administration will be having throughout the week and she admitted that there has been -- as she put it a level of visual viciousness in Washington, that caught her off guard.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

IVANKA TRUMP, PRESIDENT TRUMP'S DAUGHTER: I didn't expect it to be easy. I think some of the distractions and some of the ferocity was -- I was a little blindsided by on a personal level.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: So, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday this workforce development roll out, Dagen, Friday sources tell Fox that the President will end his workweek in Miami where he will unveil his administration's policies as it relates to Cuba. You can expect at least somewhat of a rollback of the Obama administration policies to that end.

By the way, later today here at the White House, the start off to the week the President will have a full cabinet meeting. All the members of his cabinet. Dagen, back to you.

MCDOWELL: Blake, thank you for covering all that for us. Blake Burman at the White House. Joining us now is former Texas Congressman and Republican Presidential candidate, Dr. Ron Paul. Congressman, the President is set to hold -- Blake mentioned, first full cabinet meeting today. Do you think this administration will now be able to move forward on the agenda that Americans want the reason they voted for him?

RON PAUL, FORMER TEXAS CONGRESSMAN: It is not likely but let's hope they move forward on right things because everything they say is not exactly going to solve all our problems. I don't happen to believe public works projects is a way to get more jobs. You might get more jobs but it won't be same as if you got more jobs in private sector. They make a lot of mistakes. I think obstacles are so great and people don't recognize the debt. When you have a lot of debt, it's hard to spend money. You come up with a trillion dollars for military and a trillion dollars for public works and repairing highways, where is the money going to come from? And this has an effect at marketplaces eventually. If you look at how much debt is out there whether it's automobile debt, college debt, personal debt and even housing debt right now, I mean, there is a lot of problems so that is why I think they are stymied because the fundamentals don't change. You can say these jobs -- the truth is dependent on government creating jobs or there's something wrong with the plan.

MCDOWELL: Congressman, I am going to push back in terms of the infrastructure plan and I will and you call it public works. I come on that I know that means you mean to evoke FDR's programs of the depression.

PAUL: I do, I do.

MCDOWELL: That is what you say it but trillion dollars is not going to be -- actually a minority of it would be government money. Under the way, the plan is laid out now. They would -- Trump administration would get to trillion largely in parts from funding through private investors and the money is indeed out there. It was $59 billion raised last year in private infrastructure funds. Their goal is too easy the permitting process, easy regulations to get that money invested in projects alongside the government.

PAUL: Yes. The easing of regulations is very good and that is getting out of the way house in order, but this whole thing is partnership that bothers libertarians because partnerships, big businesses big banks in government isn't exactly what a free society is all about. That is not what a Republic is about because only favored people get to do the dealing. So I don't like partnership. I want an environment where people can be competitive and produce things that are necessary. But saying that we are going to have big government financing and big business financing, there is a lot of shortcomings with that plan.

MICHAEL BLOCK, RHINO TRADING PARTNERS CHIEF STRATEGIST: Dr. Paul, Mike Block here. You raised a very valid concerns about debt levels and something people worry about except, I don't want to turn into a discussion on bond market, the bond yields are not reflecting a lot of concern about all this spending that you are talking about. The capital markets have this wrong? Is there something else going on here?

PAUL: Yes. I think they do. I am not an investor but just from an economic viewpoint, I do. You might have said tech stocks were good investment and things happen in a flash and bond markets can happen that way too, because all countries are in debt, and you know we have the European problem where you have Greece, and Italy, and Spain having problems but you are going to have something pop up. It's going to be very devastating but if you look at prices, when prices go high, when you have inflation, it is dangerous. So when you are saying bonds are pretty comfortable, you are saying that there is euphoria in the bond market; prices are very, very high; and I think it is where the bubble is right.

MCDOWELL: Congressman, I have been talking about that since 2009 and I will admit I have been dead wrong. Mitch, you got a question for the congressman? Saying that there is euphoria in the bond market prices are very, very high. And I think it is. I have been talking about that -- congressman I have been talking about that since 2009, and I will admit I have been dead wrong. Mitch, a question for the Congressman?

MITCH ROSCHELLE, FOX BUSINESS CONTRIBUTOR: You are not wrong, you are not wrong. But you can't predict his timing.

MCDOWELL: Maybe I will be right. I am sleeping in the dark. Congressman, I want Mitch to get a question for you.

ROSCHELLE: OK. When you look at the agenda with so few days really left in Session, where are the priorities? Is tax reform going to sort of fall about by way sided something we go back and reduce rates to stimulate the economy?

PAUL: When you say end of the session you mean for summer break?

ROSCHELLE: Yes, correct.

PAUL: That sort of thing?

ROSCHELLE: No. They are not going to get that done there's too many special interests. They should just be cutting, spending and cutting taxes and if you can't cut it all one time cut something. But no. They want the whole package which I understand. But it's not enough agreement. Everybody has their ax to grind. It's going to be hard to get them together besides a lot of Republicans are not dedicated to what I am talking about. They are dedicated to taking care of their friends. I mean, if -- you know, it takes medical care. They have a lot of friends in the insurance industry, and the drug industry.

They are not liable to change that and cut down real spending. They will do their talking but, Dagen, when you start cutting back it is a problem. I mean, it is hard to get an addict off drugs and that is what we're trying to do. First, I don't think they start with the basic principle. The government ought to be very limited and strive for that. They say government -- we just need better management. I don't buy into that. I think we have too much mismanagement.

MCDOWELL: Congressman, real quick. Heather.

HEATHER ZUMARRAGA, SUNAMERICA FUNDS VICE PRESIDENT: Dr. Paul, the Federal Reserve is set to hike interest rates this Wednesday. A quarter basis point. You're talking about our debt levels. What will that effect have on interest rates to service this debt?

PAUL: Oh it is going to being up, supposed the market has already discounted that, but no, if they creep up, what would happen if we had a market rate of interest which is what we need to get economy. What if interest rates were three percent? This whole worldwide system would collapse because everything depends on more and more and more now they are tinkering a quarter point here, a quarter point there. They are really not doing a whole lot so I don't think this is a trend at all.

I think this is wishful thinking. I think that if you go up a little bit more even if a little bit is going to be a bigger burden on the treasury. This is where so much production has to go eventually with increase in interest rates, and eventually interest rates will go up, then that pay all the production. We cannot pay it. We cannot pay. We have to print more money!

MCDOWELL: Yes. Keep printing. Good to see you. Congressman Ron Paul, take care of yourself.

Still ahead, do they protect too much? Stuart Varney weighs in on the outrage after New York City play used a President Trump look-alike in the role of the assassinated Julius Caesar. Why analysts are going sour on Apple.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: GE shares jumping after the company announced CEO Jeff Immelt is leaving. Nicole Petallides covering the story at New York Stock Exchange. Nicole?

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: We have this upside this morning for General Electric looking up about three percent right now, 3.7 percent so good move for GE who's been under pressure and overall but needs to cut costs and outperform a little bit. It has been under pressure. Shareholders were not too happy with Jeff Immelt particularly Trion funds and so he will be stepping down and John Flannery who is a 30-year veteran there will move up to the top spot of CEO and that will happen on August 1st. And so GE gets a pop.

Watching also Microsoft which sold off of all tech stocks on Friday but it's come out now about the new X-Box 1x. OK, this is supposed to be their smallest ever X-Box 499. Everybody is waiting for this one. It's supposed to have the graphics and the memory and speed, bandwidth and sound as well to really outpace the whole industry. And that will be available in time for the holidays.

And last but not least, watching Apple which sold off in a big way on Friday. In fact, it's biggest selloff in 14 months weighed on Dow, shaved off 41 points on Friday, it is down again cutting it this morning but still saying it's going to be strong for the holiday season, still liking the iPhone but this is really evaluation call because we have seen tech stocks really run up. And it's not even 5 percent of the 52-week high. Back to you.

MCDOWELL: Nicole, thank you so much. Nicole Petallides in the New York Stock Exchange. Another controversy surrounding creative depictions of the President. Two sponsors, major corporations, pulling out of the Shakespeare In The Park here in New York City after a production of Julius Caesar shows a Donald Trump look alike being stabbed to death on the Senate floor. Again, it's a play. It's Shakespeare. So, who do we go to? British man. Host of "VARNEY AND COMPANY," Stuart. Of course, you're going to talk about Shakespeare this morning, my friend.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK VARNEY AND COMPANY HOST: You don't know what to call me, do you? You were just kind of lost there.

MCDOWELL: I want to call you -- I was going to say, superstar.

VARNEY: No let's not get crazy. Look, I am picking up on what our viewers are seeing on the left-hand side of the screen, Shakespeare in the Park. It's really kind of pass, for New York but not voters in the rest of the country. I think they are appalled to see our President, a man looking like our President being stabbed to death in Central Park for Shakespeare in the Park. The audience apparently just loved it. That is New York, I guess. I think it is dangerous. This comes on top of the severed head from Kathy Griffin.

I just think that we are leading the country in entirely the wrong direction, leading it towards a violent confrontation between left and right. I don't think that is good for anybody. But then, let's not forget Democrat senator from New York over the weekend, dropping the "f" bomb in public right there. I have to believe that, that was focus group tried and tested. This is how you appeal to millennials, use obscene language. I think it is a dangerous situation, and I think it is something that voters are going to reject. That is where I am coming from.

MCDOWELL: I felt like when she said that, Stuart, it was the equivalent of a 3-year-old making flatulent sounds. They do it for attention.

VARNEY: Juveniles. The snickering going on in the audience and by her. It is beneath the office of senator and it should not be taking place in our country at this time.

The level of public discourse is gone down at tubes and the level of violence displayed against and the contempt displaced for our President knows no bounds I think it's counterproductive for us all.

MCDOWELL: A British gentleman. That's what I --

VARNEY: An American.

MCDOWELL: You are. You are you are the -- the represent greatest that is America in terms of the opportunities that this nation provides and how you seized upon it cherish it, I mean that Stuart, you talk about it all the time.

VARNEY: Well thank you very much indeed, Dagen, I appreciate that I do thank you.

MCDOWELL: Good to see you, we'll see you in exactly 10 minutes, Stuart, "VARNEY & COMPANY" starts every day at 9:00 a.m. Eastern time. Coming up Uber, planning to put its troubles in the rear view mirror, a key executive reportedly resigning amid questions about the company's workplace culture the fallout for the ride-sharing giant.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: The mastermind behind terror attacks on two landmarks in Iran last week apparently has been killed. Cheryl Casone has details on that.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, so Dagen according to the New York Times, the top official in Iran says that intelligence officers hunted down and killed the man behind attacks in Iran. ISIS said it is behind the assault in Iran's parliament and the Mausoleum of Ayatollah Khomeini, the founder of Islamic Republic of course that killed 17 people that attack while the newspaper says Iranian investigators are looking into the attacks, increasingly focusing a on group of radicalized Iranian Kurds.

OK. Back in here in home Uber CEO Travis Kalanick may temporarily step aside this potential move coming on the heels of Uber's board of Directors, adopting a series of recommendations about the company's corporate culture from an internal investigation from former Attorney General Eric Holder.

And a new federal audit showing that Medicare erroneously paid an estimated $729 million to doctors and other health professionals. The payments came under a multibillion-dollar federal initiative to designed shift the health care system from paper records to computers, the audit found that over three year period Medicare improperly paid health professionals since that they bonus payments under the initiative but in reality they either lacked required proof or they failed to meet the criteria for the bonuses.

And then one New Jersey couple had a surprise crasher at their wedding on Saturday. President Trump dropped by to congratulate Kristen Piatkowski and Tucker Gladhill at his Bedminster golf club. He danced with the bride, he shook hands with the guests Trump well-known for joining wedding parties at the resort said he runs, guess he used to run, you may recall back in February he and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe dropped in on a wedding reception in Mar-a-Lago. So, you know, get married at the Bedminster in Jersey and you'll never know who is going to show up, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: So far that's pretty cool.

BLOCKS: And Donald Trump.

MCDOWELL: Yes exactly, and the President of the United States doesn't drink and so you don't need to worry about him, you know, hitting the open bar, right? So maybe the food tables, not the bar, coming up final thoughts from our all-star panel.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Final thoughts from our all-stars. Mitch.

ROSCHELLE: A big week ahead we got rate hikes, Sessions testimony may be in public or private and big tech names to watch.

MCDOWELL: Buckle up, that's what you're saying.

ROSCHELLE: Buckle up.

MCDOWELL: Michael Block.

BLOCK: I'm watching the text docs too, I also want to say happy anniversary mom and dad Steve and Gloria Block.

MCDOWELL: How many years?

BLOCK: A lot.

MCDOWELL: Bad son. But he did wish you a happy anniversary on air.

ZUMARRAGA: The federal reserve is set to raise quarter basis points again on Wednesday, I'm more interested to see if they hint that unwinding their balance sheet and reducing some a little the liquidity that helps prop the markets up.

MCDOWELL: That we probably won't find out until the fall I think Septembers the application for that.

ZUMARRAGA: Maybe. MCDOWELL: Thanks to Heather and Michael and Mitch, see you all. And Maria will be back tomorrow. She's going to interview Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin at 7 a.m. Eastern time, and then we go to the U.S. open but right now it's "VARNEY & COMPANY" Stuart Varney.

END

urn:contentItem:5NSR-DNJ1-DY0W-434S-00000-00New Agenda Push; Outrage In The Park; Jeff Immelt Stepping Down; Penguins Win Stanley Cup; Flier-In-Chief; President Trump Travel Ban Push;2017-06-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:44ZLexisNexisNew Agenda Push; Outrage In The Park; Jeff Immelt Stepping Down; Penguins Win Stanley Cup; Flier-In-Chief; President Trump Travel Ban Push;LanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, June 12th. Your top stories at 8:00 a.m. Eastern Time. Getting the agenda back on track, President Trump expected to unveil a new jobs push in Wisconsin, tomorrow. The move comes as the White House moves past the controversy surrounding Jim Comey's testimony last week. First Daughter, Ivanka Trump, was asked on "FOX & FRIENDS" earlier about her father's response to that controversy.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

IVANKA TRUMP, DAUGHTER OF PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP: My father felt very vindicated in all the statements that he has been making and feels incredibly optimistic but, you know, at the White House and throughout the administration we were incredibly focused on the reason we all went to Washington.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Sure.

TRUMP: And what we're fighting for. So last week, while it didn't get the level of headlines, it will ultimately have a much more important impact, it was infrastructure week, focusing on the commitment to rebuild this country.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: More from Ivanka Trump's interview ahead. Outrage in Central Park, a New York City play using a President Trump look-alike for the role of the assassinated Julius Caesar. The fallout as both Delta and Bank of America pulled their sponsorships.

Breaking news this morning, Jeff Immelt out at General Electric. The company announcing earlier this morning that he will be replaced by John Flannery as chairman and CEO. Flannery, the current president and CEO of G.E. Healthcare. G.E. shares up three percent on the news, that stock down this year, down in the last year, and down about 28 percent during Immelt's tenure since 2001.

Futures are showing losses across the board, 34-point loss on the Dow Futures, we keep a very close eye on what happens with technology stocks. These big names, your Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, Google, Apple, and Microsoft had been your major market leaders, pulling the rest of the market along all year and they took a beating on Friday and many of them lower in premarket trading.

In Europe, stocks also heading south, we have a one percent loss in France and in Germany. Same story in Asia overnight, you have red across your screen with the biggest loser there being the Hang Seng, down one and a quarter percent.

And the Penguins putting the Predators on ice. Pittsburgh topping Nashville to win its second straight Stanley Cup. The highlights from that big win ahead. Plus, Jimmy Carter, the president - former president taking flight, the former leader of the free world, a video of him going viral after he took the time to great everyone on his plane. The presidential surprise for passengers, the surprise being Mr. Carter was flying commercial. There you go. All of that -- cancer survivor, by the way, as well, all of that and so much more coming up.

Financial analyst, Heather Zumarraga, Rhino Trading Partners Chief Strategist, Michael Block, and PwC Partner, Mitch Roschelle. Good to see you, one and all, this morning.

HEATHER ZUMARRAGA, SUNAMERICA FUNDS VICE PRESIDENT: Good morning.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: What's on your mind? Immelt out.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PWC PARTNER & BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT LEADER: I'm interested to see what happens with those big tech names because if they start to continue to sell off, they're so heavy in the indices, that it could start dragging the market down and start getting everybody worried that Trump rally is a thing of the past.

ZUMARRAGA: Dated. NASDAQ down 1.8 percent on Friday. We'll see if we get some follow through today to see if there's a sector rotation, as the NASDAQ is pulling back, the Dow has been hitting new all-time highs.

MCDOWELL: And the Russell 2000, the small-cap stocks (INAUDIBLE) a record on Friday.

(CROSSTALK)

ROSCHELLE: That's a good story though.

MICHAEL BLOCK, RHINO TRADING PARTNERS CHIEF STRATEGIST: The Russell caught up too. Yes.

ZUMARRAGA: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

BLOCK: Russell caught up because everyone was shorted?

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: Sector rotation.

BLOCK: No, no. It's squeezing. Full state of rotation continues.

ROSCHELLE: And the Fed is hiking this week.

ZUMARRAGA: Yes. Very important.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: No. I mean, take that one to the bank I think what Jon Hilsenrath would have done.

(CROSSTALK)

ROSCHELLE: -- got lost in the headlines when you never know what happens with Sessions' testimony. So .

MCDOWELL: We'll keep it in the headlines right here on Fox Business as we always do.

ROSCHELLE: There you go.

MCDOWELL: We can talk about everything. Joining the conversation this morning, former Texas Congressman Presidential Candidate, Ron Paul, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY", Mr. Stuart Varney. We always love to see Mr. Varney. To our story this hour, today is the deadline for parties challenging the president's travel ban to respond to a petition from justice department.

The petition asks the Supreme Court to allow the president's executive order to go into effect. Despite opposition, Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton says the president has the right to enact this ban. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KEN PAXTON, TEXAS ATTORNEY GENERAL: We think we're absolutely right on the law, there's a federal law that clearly gives the president the authority to do this. This travel ban is right in line with that statute. And so, we're confident if the court actually follows federal law, that the president will be just fine.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Joining me now is the co-founder of Diligence LLC, former CIA Operative Mike Baker. I don't even know where you are but I know you parachuted in or tunneled in.

MIKE BAKER, FORMER CIA OPERATIVE: He can't tell you where he is. I'm at the - I'm at the compound right now. It's a secret - it's a secret location except I got a picture of it behind me.

MCDOWELL: This is why you have to - this is why you have to follow Mike on Twitter because it's always like he's on a - like a gator boat, like a fan boat coming in.

BAKER: Get in your boat --

MCDOWELL: Mike, is these bans a significant step in focusing on national security?

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK VARNEY AND COMPANY HOST: You don't know what to call me, do you? You were just kind of lost there.

MCDOWELL: I want to call you -- I was going to say, superstar.

VARNEY: No let's not get crazy. Look, I am picking up on what our viewers are seeing on the left-hand side of the screen, Shakespeare in the Park. It's really kind of pass, for New York but not voters in the rest of the country. I think they are appalled to see our President, a man looking like our President being stabbed to death in Central Park for Shakespeare in the Park. The audience apparently just loved it. That is New York, I guess. I think it is dangerous. This comes on top of the severed head from Kathy Griffin.

I just think that we are leading the country in entirely the wrong direction, leading it towards a violent confrontation between left and right. I don't think that is good for anybody. But then, let's not forget Democrat senator from New York over the weekend, dropping the "f" bomb in public right there. I have to believe that, that was focus group tried and tested. This is how you appeal to millennials, use obscene language. I think it is a dangerous situation, and I think it is something that voters are going to reject. That is where I am coming from.

MCDOWELL: I felt like when she said that, Stuart, it was the equivalent of a 3-year-old making flatulent sounds. They do it for attention.

VARNEY: Juveniles. The snickering going on in the audience and by her. It is beneath the office of senator and it should not be taking place in our country at this time.

The level of public discourse is gone down at tubes and the level of violence displayed against and the contempt displaced for our President knows no bounds I think it's counterproductive for us all.

MCDOWELL: A British gentleman. That's what I --

VARNEY: An American.

MCDOWELL: You are. You are you are the -- the represent greatest that is America in terms of the opportunities that this nation provides and how you seized upon it cherish it, I mean that Stuart, you talk about it all the time.

VARNEY: Well thank you very much indeed, Dagen, I appreciate that I do thank you.

MCDOWELL: Good to see you, we'll see you in exactly 10 minutes, Stuart, "VARNEY & COMPANY" starts every day at 9:00 a.m. Eastern time. Coming up Uber, planning to put its troubles in the rear view mirror, a key executive reportedly resigning amid questions about the company's workplace culture the fallout for the ride-sharing giant.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: The mastermind behind terror attacks on two landmarks in Iran last week apparently has been killed. Cheryl Casone has details on that.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, so Dagen according to the New York Times, the top official in Iran says that intelligence officers hunted down and killed the man behind attacks in Iran. ISIS said it is behind the assault in Iran's parliament and the Mausoleum of Ayatollah Khomeini, the founder of Islamic Republic of course that killed 17 people that attack while the newspaper says Iranian investigators are looking into the attacks, increasingly focusing a on group of radicalized Iranian Kurds.

OK. Back in here in home Uber CEO Travis Kalanick may temporarily step aside this potential move coming on the heels of Uber's board of Directors, adopting a series of recommendations about the company's corporate culture from an internal investigation from former Attorney General Eric Holder.

And a new federal audit showing that Medicare erroneously paid an estimated $729 million to doctors and other health professionals. The payments came under a multibillion-dollar federal initiative to designed shift the health care system from paper records to computers, the audit found that over three year period Medicare improperly paid health professionals since that they bonus payments under the initiative but in reality they either lacked required proof or they failed to meet the criteria for the bonuses.

And then one New Jersey couple had a surprise crasher at their wedding on Saturday. President Trump dropped by to congratulate Kristen Piatkowski and Tucker Gladhill at his Bedminster golf club. He danced with the bride, he shook hands with the guests Trump well-known for joining wedding parties at the resort said he runs, guess he used to run, you may recall back in February he and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe dropped in on a wedding reception in Mar-a-Lago. So, you know, get married at the Bedminster in Jersey and you'll never know who is going to show up, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: So far that's pretty cool.

BLOCKS: And Donald Trump.

MCDOWELL: Yes exactly, and the President of the United States doesn't drink and so you don't need to worry about him, you know, hitting the open bar, right? So maybe the food tables, not the bar, coming up final thoughts from our all-star panel.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Final thoughts from our all-stars. Mitch.

ROSCHELLE: A big week ahead we got rate hikes, Sessions testimony may be in public or private and big tech names to watch.

MCDOWELL: Buckle up, that's what you're saying.

ROSCHELLE: Buckle up.

MCDOWELL: Michael Block.

BLOCK: I'm watching the text docs too, I also want to say happy anniversary mom and dad Steve and Gloria Block.

MCDOWELL: How many years?

BLOCK: A lot.

MCDOWELL: Bad son. But he did wish you a happy anniversary on air.

ZUMARRAGA: The federal reserve is set to raise quarter basis points again on Wednesday, I'm more interested to see if they hint that unwinding their balance sheet and reducing some a little the liquidity that helps prop the markets up.

MCDOWELL: That we probably won't find out until the fall I think Septembers the application for that.

ZUMARRAGA: Maybe. MCDOWELL: Thanks to Heather and Michael and Mitch, see you all. And Maria will be back tomorrow. She's going to interview Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin at 7 a.m. Eastern time, and then we go to the U.S. open but right now it's "VARNEY & COMPANY" Stuart Varney.

END
