urn:contentItem:5YG3-32M1-JDPT-T0J3-00000-00New America Holds Discussion on 5 and Affordable Connectivity2020-03-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:44ZLexisNexisNew America Holds Discussion on 5 and Affordable Connectivity

New America Holds Discussion On 5g And Affordable Connectivity

March 17, 2020 12:00 P.M.

SPEAKERS:

FEDERAL COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION COMMISSIONER MICHAEL O'RIELLY

FEDERAL COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION COMMISSIONER JESSICA ROSENWORCEL

FACEBOOK CONNECTIVITY & ACCESS PUBLIC POLICY MANAGER PRISCILLA DELGADO

ARGERIS TECHNOLOGY POLICY INSTITUTE SENIOR FELLOW JOHN HORRIGAN

MICROSOFT GOVERNMENT & REGULATORY AFFAIRS SENIOR DIRECTOR PAULA BOYD

ALLVANZA CEO ROSA MENDOZA

PRINCE WILLIAM COUNTY PUBLIC SCHOOLS INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY SERVICES DIRECTOR AJ PHILLIPS

NEW AMERICA'S OPEN TECHNOLOGY INSTITUTE WIRELESS FUTURE PROJECT DIRECTOR MICHAEL CALABRESE

[*]CALABRESE: Well, hello everyone and welcome to New America's virtual edition of our Wireless Future Event, Next Generation Wi-Fi Heading Off a 5G Digital Divide with Affordable Connectivity for All. I am Michael Calabrese. I direct the Wireless Future Project at New America's Open Technology Institute and we have a--a great lineup for you. What we had hoped of course to see most of you in person and it is unfortunate of course for so many reasons that we cannot but we wanted to make sure that we took the opportunity to help you know educate the policy community further about this really important issue which we believe is--is coming up to a vote very soon at the FCC and we will hear about that from our--from two of the commissioners momentarily.

Over the past few years, what many have called the race to 5G has focused primarily on auctioning thousands of megahertz of licensed spectrum in the high-frequency bands, millimeter wave, and now particularly this year in the--in the mid-band range that would be you know C-band spectrum and 2.5 GHz in particular. However, making 5G wireless connectivity and applications available and affordable to all Americans every--everywhere will also depend on opening large new bands of unlicensed spectrum capable of supporting the next generation of gigabit fast Wi-Fi which is--has a new designation Wi-Fi 6 which you will be hearing a lot about.

Building out mobile carrier 5G will be costly; it will take many years and focus initially on urban and high traffic areas. In contrast, Wi-Fi 6 is--is--is ready now and can make 5G capable connectivity available in any home, business, school, library, or public space that has a--a fiber, cable, or other fast fixed broadband connection nearby. What we need is more spectrum, which is what we will talk about.

The problem is that the spectrum bands available for Wi-Fi and unlicensed public use are becoming very congested, particularly in higher traffic areas and insufficient to power 5G-capable apps and services of the near future. The FCC is expected to vote next month on a proposal to allow Wi-Fi 6 to share 1200 MHz of underutilized spectrum across the entire 6 GHz band. This is spectrum you know used for tens of thousands of point to point microwave links and--and other services.

The commission has also proposed to reallocate 45 MHz of unused spectrum in the adjacent auto safety band at 5.9 GHz which would create--which will create we hope the first unencumbered gigabit fast Wi-Fi channel there adding onto what has today become the workhorse band for 5G just below the auto safety band. The new unlicensed spectrum is necessary to make Wi-Fi 6 a pillar of a world-leading 5G ecosystem able to provide gigabit fast and affordable capacity needed to connect billions of devices in smart homes, classrooms, public venues and for enterprise IoT networks.

So with that we will move on to the--the program, the run of show is that we are going to begin with an overview presentation of Wi-Fi 6 and the spectrum it uses by Priscilla Delgado Argeris of Facebook who I will introduce momentarily and then commissioners O'Rielly and Rosenworcel will join me for a discussion and then we will end with a panel which will be led off by John Horrigan from Tech Policy Institute who is going to give overview of the digital divide and then we will have a discussion that also includes Paula Boyd from Microsoft, Rosa Mendoza from Allvanza and AJ Phillips from the Prince William County Public Schools.

So with that, I would like to introduce Priscilla, Priscilla Delgado Argeris is the public policy manager for Connectivity and Access at Facebook and the former senior legal advisor to Commissioner Rosenworcel for wireless public safety and international issues. Priscilla?

DELGADO ARGERIS: Hi, there. I think I have some slides, so I am just going to wait for those to start loading up, but I think you can go to the next slide. You know, thanks everyone for joining. I think Michael asked me to come and do this a couple of weeks ago I never imagined I would be doing it from my house with my kids who are in the next room who we are trying not so successfully yet on the homeschooling and I think all of you are probably working from home, maybe trying to do the same thing.

Maybe you are just thinking about the millions of students who don't have access to broadband at home and how they are going to fair over the next weeks and possibly months, but I think it is probably safe to say that Wi-Fi and conductivity and home broadband are all on our minds today. So I just want to talk a little bit more about the importance of Wi-Fi but also the important--the need for more spectrum for Wi-Fi and why the 6 GHz band is going to be so important in meeting that need. So if we can go to the next slide.

Okay. So I think today it's just becoming so apparent as we are trying to adjust our lives to this current crisis, but Wi-Fi is key to economic growth and to society as a whole. Citizens, businesses, and governments are increasingly relying on Wi-Fi and unlicensed spectrum. Mobile operators use Wi-Fi extensively to offload traffic from their networks. Wi-Fi drives GDP growth by providing low-cost, high-speed broadband access, and using Wi-Fi also and Wi-Fi to build other technologies, organizations can develop new innovative digital services and business models. And if you look at these graphics, you can see you know the value of Wi-Fi is estimated in 2018 to be $499 billion in the U.S. alone and almost double that is projected, and it tracks the same type of growth globally.

Next slide. So you know Wi-Fi is an important complement to home broadband, which we all know, but it is also critical; it's going to be a critical complement to 5G. Right now, Wi-Fi supports the offload of 54 percent of mobile data traffic, and this is set to grow to about 70 percent 5G, as you can see. Next slide.

So Michael mentioned Wi-Fi 6 which is the sort of next-generation Wi-Fi standard, which is ultra-fast, low latency, and Wi-Fi 6 and 5G we expect will work hand in hand because without the ability to offload traffic to Wi-Fi 5G networks will have to be more expensive and less sufficient. Mobile operators would need to invest more in network densification, deploying more small cells in dense urban area in order to get that gigabit throughput.

Wi-Fi 6 can support 5G use cases such as HD video streaming, Wi-Fi calling, smart home devices, hotspot access, the automation of citywide services, AR/VR application, health monitoring devices, wearables, and seamless roam--roaming. And as we have been talking about, robust Wi-Fi is really critical to bridging the digital divide. I think we are all living this with kids that are switching to distance-learning and you know as Commissioner Rosenworcel, my old boss, has said many times 70 percent of teachers are assigning homework that requires Internet access even in normal circumstances so Wi-Fi is a really important tool for anchor institutions like schools and libraries to close that homework gap for students that don't have reliable home broadband. Next slide.

So we've talked a lot about why Wi-Fi is important, and we all understand that, but what not everyone is thinking about is that we need more spectrum for Wi-Fi because the current Wi-Fi bands we use are getting congested. As U.S. operators are rolling out this gigabit broadband networks, you have to have really robust Wi-Fi in your home to be able to actually appreciate that to get it to all of your devices, to get it to multiple devices in a household that are streaming at the same time and we don't want Wi-Fi to become a bottleneck to user experience. It has also been more than 20 years since new mid-band spectrum has been made available for Wi-Fi despite this exponential growth in traffic, and unless action is taken, there is estimates that the U.S. is going to have a shortfall of 1.6 GHz by 2025. That will impact businesses and consumers. Next slide.

So this chart shows the 6 GHz band, and the spectrum that is available and how that spectrum would be divided into channels and what is so important about the 6 GHz band is that it can--if the whole band becomes available for unlicensed use that would mean 760 MHz channels and if you see below, it can show you under different Wi-Fi standards what data rates could be achieved and how fast that could be. Just by comparison, Michael mentioned the 5.9 GHz proceeding which is also super important but the Wi-Fi in that--in that band they're--they're looking to make one 160 MHz new megahertz channel available so to really add a lot of those superfast channels we really need the 6 GHz band. Next slide.

So in the 6 GHz band industry has been talking about three different device classes and so the first would be a very low--very low power portable device class with a max sort of peak 14 dBm EIRP limit and this would operate both indoors and outdoors. A low-power indoor device class and a standard power device class that would have automated frequency control. Next slide.

So starting out with VLP these are some of the possible use cases. Mobile AR/VR, UHD video streaming, high-speed tethering, and in-vehicle entertainment. These are you know 2 Gb high throughput and very low latency in close distances. Next slide.

So in terms of VLP, this is the space where you would have next-generation mobile peripherals, critical 5G use cases like immersive AR/VR connectivity and other advanced peripherals would rely on 6 GHz VLP because of the constraints on battery life, form factor, and cost. And one example would be the connection between augmented reality glasses and a smartphone that would be a VLP device and something that you know we have been talking about at Facebook is that AR/VR really isn't just--I think people think oh, that's gaming or something like that but if you think now that we are all working from home you can imagine you know you do feel that distance even with a video call. Imagine if you had devices in AR/VR that could really make you feel present at work and what that would mean if you could really work from everywhere for any company and so that is something that we are talking a lot about. Next slide.

Okay. 6 GHz also enables robust low-power indoor use cases, and those are high speeds, 1.4 GHz at a 7 meter distance even if there are obstructions. Next slide. And then standard power use cases. That is like enterprise use cases, 20 GHz per second, outdoor coverage, parks, and stadiums and also there are opportunities for rural connectivity with multi-gigahertz bit point to multipoint services. Next slide.

Next slide, yeah. Perfect. So obviously the 6 (INAUDIBLE) gigahertz band it is not greenfield spectrum; there are existing users and their important users, but we believe that this unlicensed use can be compatible with those existing incumbents. Low-power indoor and very low power devices protect incumbent operations by design. Low-power and indoor-only low power is indoor only. There would be rules that would require it to be plugged in, there would be removable antennas and couldn't be weatherproofed than that would all ensure that these devices would be used indoors.

Very low power, has an extremely low radiant power and dynamic power control and what that means is if you have on you know AR glasses for example if you are in a situation where there was less body loss the power would automatically reduce because you need to save battery life and so you would never have a situation where you are going over the peak power, but this added benefit of dynamic power control that you would have in battery-operated devices also ensure that you are always operating at the lowest power possible. There are other elements in VLP, including body loss, antennae mismatch that would help to prevent any harmful interference to 6 GHz incumbents.

And then lastly, the standard power 6 GHz devices would protect incumbent operations with automated frequency control. The devices obtain a list of permissible operating frequencies from the AFC system operator. Next slide.

So, in summary, the U.S. really needs to act on unlicensed spectrum. Wi-Fi is the key to economic growth and societal development, key to achieving the U.S. connectivity goals. It is key to 5G, and it is a key part of bridging the digital divide. Wi-Fi's full potential can only be realized with access to more unlicensed spectrum, and the 6 GHz band is really a perfect fit. The U.S. must act now to ensure 6 GHz spectrum is available on a technology-neutral unlicensed basis as soon as possible. That's it for me.

CALABRESE: Hello? Thanks, Priscilla, in case that wasn't heard. That was--that was terrific, and if you are able to stay around at the end, in fact, I meant to mention this that we will have a chance for audience questions at the--at the end of the event although I believe the commissioners will be willing to take a couple time permitting.

So let's move--let's move on to our discussion with commissioners Mike O'Rielly and Jessica Rosenworcel because we are all anxious to hear from--from you both. You know you don't need any extended introduction except that I would like to both make sure that everyone knows you know how much we appreciate the leadership that both of you have shown for many years in championing a vision of wireless ecosystem that is you know balanced between licensed and unlicensed that has the full powers of both and you have both really lead the way in opening more spectrum at 5.9 GHz and across 6 GHz for the next generation of Wi-Fi that we are here to discuss. So this is really very much part of a culmination of--of all of your efforts for--for years. So I just wanted to--to recognize that.

So to I guess to get us rolling, what can you tell us about when the commission is likely to adopt the 6 GHz border and also how much additional spectrum capacity can we reasonably expect?

O'RIELLY: Okay. I guess that is thrown to my direction first.

CALABRESE: Sure.

O'RIELLY: Appreciate (INAUDIBLE) being on the call as well or on--on the video. I was very confident that we were going to see an item very shortly. Next month seemed an appropriate time. I am not sure that events haven't changed that timeline. I haven't had a chance to talk to the chairman, so I'm trying to be respectful. It had been something that was teed up and--and worked with over the last couple of pieces, and I would like to believe that we can still make that happen, but I have to also be mindful that everything else that is happening and be mindful of what type of commission meeting we may have so I--I would like to believe we can still make that momentarily and still be available next month.

In terms of your second part of your question, how much that is to be worked out. That is something we are working hard on. I have commented in the past about how much I would like to make the whole band available for the three purposes that--that Priscilla mentioned, try and work through all three scenarios that they all be operational, not one over the other. I am certainly mindful low-power indoor is certainly really important to me, but all of them are important and they all have benefits and will really help the community that so needed--needs additional spectrum.

So I am very happy where things are. I had a chance to Wi-Fi 6e a couple of weeks ago, and I am really excited where things are. There have been proposals, and I am sure we will get into them to do some license in that portion. I haven't find those proposals viable as of yet, but I will keep an open mind.

CALABRESE: Commissioner Rosenworcel?

ROSENWORCEL: All right. Can you hear me? All right. I cosign and agree with everything my colleague Commissioner O'Rielly just said.

For starters, we do need to move fast. The 5G economy is underway, and so much of the focus of our discussion has been on licensed spectrum. It is really important that we think about unlicensed at the same time and the 6 GHz band is a terrific place to do it and just like my colleague I hope we can make as much spectrum available as possible in that band so that we see truly fast speeds and we see as much innovation as we can make possible. So I am hopeful we will get to this in April but I again like my colleague recognize that these are complex times and the agency might need to make some hard decisions, but I do want to thank Commissioner O'Reilly because I know that he has been vigorous in championing that we move on this issue as fast as possible and that is a large part of why we were planning to work on this in April.

CALABRESE: Okay. Well as a follow-up to what you just said I mentioned at the very opening that what many call the race to 5G has focused almost entirely on--on mobile carrier networks and it's not even clear that many you know I think in this policy community we understand the nuances, but you know the broader context may not be as clear to many on the Hill and in other places. Do you view the next generation of Wi-Fi technology as part of the future 5G wireless ecosystem, and is it complimentary? And I guess Commissioner Rosenworcel can start since you are up.

ROSENWORCEL: Sure. Sure, absolutely. Listen, I think Priscilla said it really well when she pointed out that 70 percent of 5G traffic is expected at some point to be offloaded onto Wi-Fi networks. So if we don't create more spectrum for Wi-Fi right now what we are going to have is these super-fast licensed networks that are like being on a highway, and then we are going to get off on a gravel road, and it will radically reduce our ability to do new and innovative things at high speeds with low latency so it's key for all of us to keep in mind that statistic that Priscilla offered which is 70 percent of 5G traffic is expected to be offloaded on the Wi-Fi. It's why we've got to think about how we can have more unlicensed spectrum, and we need to do it now.

O'RIELLY: And I would say I completely view these as complementary and join my colleague's comments and thank her for all of her hard work on these tough issues. We have worked together on a bunch of matters, but these are two particular items both 5.9 and 6 GHz that I have appreciated her--her input, her thoughts, and her hard work on the matter.

Now to--to your question I--I certainly agree the point in terms of offloading traffic. That--that is a big point, but I just see the change in the communities that the folks that I have been working with for decades on the matter a change of attitude. I certainly believe we are still going to need licensed spectrum, and I work really hard on 5G bands to make those available, but I also believe that we have to have a complementarity full portfolio of unlicensed spectrum and--and that is where you are seeing the licensed community change.

In the past, it was a vicious fight between (INAUDIBLE) and now you are seeing an acceptance, but that doesn't mean that that particular band is not going to--you know not going to be contested, but you are seeing and understanding the value from both the licensed community and certainly the unlicensed community. So I think we are going to see you know more appreciation from the licensed community. We are still going to need licensed bands. There is no panacea going forward, and we are still going to have to work really hard, but they all complement each other.

CALABRESE: Okay. So and that's a perfect segue to my next question, which is that you know in real-time we're--we're all grappling with school closures in a majority of states including the nation's largest school districts. That could dramatically worsen what Commissioner Rosenworcel has for many years called the homework gap.

Would you--would you support the use of emergency funds to pay for Wi-Fi hotspots, waivers of e-rate restrictions, or any other measures that could help families get through the shutdown? Just an opportunity to kind of address the--what is going on you know right now in front of us in terms of the connectivity crunch at home? Commissioner Rosenworcel do you have--(INAUDIBLE) start talking it will switch to you.

ROSENWORCEL: Yeah, sure. Listen, as a nation, we are heading online like never before. We have got nearly 40 million schoolchildren who have been told that their schools are shuttering, and millions of them have been told to go online for class. This is a huge experiment in remote learning that this crisis has made necessary, but it is also exposing really hard truths about the scope of the digital divide, what I call the homework gap.

So many students need Internet access for nightly schoolwork but data from the Senate, from (INAUDIBLE), lots of folks proves time and again that so many students don't have that access and now with everyone expected to work and learn at home we have a crisis on our hands, and I think the FCC should use every emergency power it has to step up and make sure it's e-rate program can cover the cost of Wi-Fi hotspots for loan in our school libraries, so no child is left off-line.

I think we should mirror our efforts on what was done following Hurricane Katrina during the Bush administration when we made a lot of really big decisions really fast about how we could use our universal service programs to keep folks connected. Now is the time to do exactly the same thing because we can fix this homework gap, but we have got to move fast.

O'RIELLY: Well, I would say it's--I am incredibly mindful of the circumstances just before me in my own personal life but also talking to the countless people over the years the need to expand broadband accessibility it is paramount priority for me. I have worked really hard in trying to address the unserved population and make sure that the commission stays focused on that to really get broadband to everyone who doesn't have it today and we can--we can disagree over the numbers of how many people are not connected, but we know that that population is significant and whether it's one person or 50 million it doesn't matter to me I want to make sure everyone has an opportunity to--to access the broadband.

In terms of the immediate crisis that we face, I am willing to look at anything that is available. I know that we don't have the authority to waive the statute. That is something that Congress can do, and I know that they are looking at some of these things and will have the opportunity to consider those--those policy changes. So in--in--in working with my former employers I hopefully will be able to find a policy that works for everyone (INAUDIBLE) very short order.

CALABRESE: Okay. Any thoughts about you know sort of the add-on to that telework which is becoming at least you know sort of immediately a new normal, and you know could--this could change the degree to which it is done even after this--even after we get through this crisis.

There is a very interesting article just today in the New York Times about how there could be you know millions of homes with you know even with good cable Internet where you have two adults trying to do video conferencing for work in addition to children hopefully doing schoolwork, but maybe watching their own video. Now I know you can't wave a magic wand and you know and say that this all this additional unlicensed spectrum is available immediately but--but you know I think it's a good thought experiment that if Wi-Fi 6 and access to the 5.9 and 6 GHz bands were available now, you know with this connectivity crunch be less of a problem?

That's such a good--that's such a good point. Look, we are in the middle of a crisis right now, and I'd like everyone else wants to get to the other side, and when we do, I hope we take measurements of where our network succeeded and where they failed because it's not simple getting connectivity to everyone's household. You could have challenges with backhaul, with interconnection points, with the last mile and, of course, with our home Wi-Fi systems.

In addition, you could have platforms we all use to communicate that might be overloaded. You could also have virtual private networks that enterprise use for telework that really were not made for the load that they are going to have in the coming weeks. So I hope when this is all done, we can look back and identify those points of failure, and I think when we do, we are going to learn that we need more Wi-Fi and the 6 GHz band as a really good place to start.

CALABRESE: (INAUDIBLE) O'Rielly any thoughts?

O'RIELLY: I would--I would certainly agree with the points my--my fellow colleague made. I--I might say I would complement it and say we are going to learn a lot of lessons learned will be both positive, and there will be some negative and at any point in the communication network there may be a breakdown because of load and demand, and that is something we will have to explore going forward, and what are those within our authority and others that are--that are outside our report so there will be lessons learned good ones and a lot of up--uplifting will be done from the magical things that the people were able to do during this time, and there will be some sad stories that we will have to deal with that will change policies going forward.

So we are going to learn a lot, and we have a lot to do. Wi-Fi will play--is already playing an incredible important role in connecting consumers and enterprises today and in this moment that we live and so I am really appreciative of what has come before me, the work that has come before me, the things that I might have done in a different life and now I know all of the work that we have to do on 5.9 and 6 GHz and those are heavy lifting things. I--I have been there from the beginning, and I am very pleased that we're all getting close to completion.

CALABRESE: Okay. Well, on a more uplifting note, we have talked about education. Commissioner Rosenworcel?

ROSENWORCEL: One of the things that I think is most exciting is we are going to see the growth of the intelligent edge. O'RIELLY: I would agree, and I appreciate all of the points that Priscilla made in her presentation. CALABRESE: Okay, great. So to a new topic, our panel in a bit, we will focus on the digital divide and Wi-Fi's role in narrowing the gap. O'RIELLY: I--I would join my colleague's comments. I might have lost a little bit in there, but I'm sure she said some wonderful things and I would agree with her on them. But I--like I said I am really excited on what--where--and the places where Wi-Fi can--can fill in its role that it will play.

CALABRESE: Okay, thank you. CALABRESE: Okay. Commissioner Rosenworcel, anything on this?

CALABRESE: Right. I believe it was at the WRC primarily Huawei and China that was you know pushing for us even to look at potentially licensing in the upper 6 GHz.

ROSENWORCEL: Right. Yeah, no, I think it was purchased by China, for I think it is region two which involves Europe and Africa to study the use of this band for licensed airwaves at the next ITU gathering, which could be 2023. O'RIELLY: I agree with my colleague and say you know I had the chance to be in Egypt for the WRC and I will tell you, you know, my experience where those countries to disrupt U.S. Wi-Fi experiences and to slow our success globally and then disrupt that process those companies you mentioned, the countries you mentioned are more disruptive than it was about strategic actually licensing and being thoughtful going forward. CALABRESE: Yeah, that is interesting. O'RIELLY: I--I will take that to start as I don't see my colleague right at the moment.

CALABRESE: Yeah, go ahead.

O'RIELLY: So I think that all three tracks are necessary and I think that I--I appreciate the--the license community working together and not fighting amongst each other to try and make one track over another track, so I think all three are--are necessary and inevitable and will be part of our item whenever it is considered.

CALABRESE: Yeah, I think that's the general belief. Commissioner?

ROSENWORCEL: I agree. I think my colleague said it well. CALABRESE: Yeah, well, we are, of course, pleased to hear that since our very broad-based you know consumer civil rights education etc. coalitions have made that our--our top priority for the general public. O'RIELLY: Well, my take would be that we have--we have greater experience, right? We have done you know (INAUDIBLE) has worked to address a number of problems that we had on (INAUDIBLE) white spaces. And so I think the experience has really calmed down a lot of the waters from incumbent users from DOD and other--others and so I think an AFC makes--makes incredible sense for the certain power level that we are talking about, the track that we are talking about, the one track of the three in--in 6 GHZ.

But I think it is also mindful that we not overload that, that we not expect that doesn't necessarily have to be a full some SaaS-type structure that we can build a less requirement and not burdensome not be as expensive as--as we have had in the past. So experience has helped us a lot, experience on both sides right and making sure that it's not too cumbersome in the process.

CALABRESE: Okay. Commissioner Rosenworcel?

ROSENWORCEL: I--I agree with my colleague again. Like pause and remember it wasn't that long ago that it was perceived as totally radical to have a spectrum access system, and these things would never work, but here we are, and we have got proof of concept. Like you said, it is almost revolutionary switch in our thinking, and it is passing us by, but we should pause and note it is really important that it has happened.

CALABRESE: And--and I would like to add you know I think to your credit that the FCC is the again leading the world on this. And similarly they are starting to open C-band spectrum for sharing for small enterprise use and so on but again they are doing it through manual coordination which is very clunky and limiting because they have no experience with this sort of leading-edge use of dynamic database coordination that we have in the U.S.

So again I--you know I think you should take some credit for leading the world on this. It is going to be really important. I think in the--in 5--in the whole broader 5G ecosystem.

O'RIELLY: (INAUDIBLE) mindful that it is not just this commission, it is folks that were lot working on this for a long while before I got to the commission. So we will just have to see who--who is right going forward.

CALABRESE: Okay. Well, we are almost out of time, but I do want to ask the last question on my end about the 5.9 GHz band. You know comments were just filed on that last week. One argument we are seeing from the auto industry is that reallocating 45 MHz to unlicensed and Wi-Fi is just a small increment. It is not needed considering the far larger amounts that could soon be available at 6 GHz. So I am wondering how you think about that. I mean, you both made 5.9 a priority. Is it really just a marginal 40 or 45 MHz, or is it something more important? Commissioner O'Rielly?

O'RIELLY: Well, look, at 5.9 incredibly important. I disagree with some of the auto industry, and I wouldn't say it's the car manufacturers who have switched their tune over the last many years and so I think the infrastructure side is still you know committed to a DS RC model, and all 75 MHz must be preserved. I don't think it is sustainable going forward, and I think that their approach is problematic. They have been you know so much hyperbole on this subject it is incredibly not helpful to the entire dialogue.

But I think what you get from 5.9 is not something that is identical to a 6 GHz though they are really close and we can put 5.9 to work immediately. There would be more work needed to make the AFC operational and 6 GHz to deal with some of the things so notwithstanding adopting an item there will be more work to have 6--to make 6 GHz operational where we can plug in 5.9 almost immediate and so I think that is really telling and something that I think the auto industry as a whole or the transportation industry as a whole is missing on the situation.

CALABRESE: Okay. Commissioner?

ROSENWORCEL: I think my colleague just said that very well, but I--I think there's a bigger macro issue here. Two years ago, in appropriations legislation Congress asked the FCC to find 255 MHz of spectrum, and as much of that would be 155 MHz below 8 GHz for unlicensed use.

So, on the one hand, we have Congress tasking us with identifying airwaves that can be cleared for unlicensed use and a lot of them, and that is a great thing. They understand just as Priscilla mentioned that this is big for the economy; let's have more of it, but at the same time, we have a lot of federal entities that are incumbent users in 8 gig and below 8 GHz and they are pushing back on the agency whenever we try to reclaim those airwaves or even try to come up with waves where we can use them together, and this is not a problem that is unique to this administration.

Frankly, it is as old as time, and on a going-forward basis for us to have a robust wireless economy with both licensed and unlicensed, we are going to have to get better at this because the back and forth slows down what we can do with these airwaves and slows down innovation and I think we are going to reach the point where it slows the economy too.

So this is a bigger picture problem than just what we see in the 5.9 GHz band. It is something that we are going to have to address at a higher level because this back and forth isn't getting us always the airwaves we need.

CALABRESE: That's right. Thank you, commissioners. That is something I forgot to do at the outset is wish everyone a happy St. Patrick's Day. It is so hard to remember when you are not seeing anyone dressed in green, although I should since I am half Irish believe it or not in spite of my last name.

So we can move on to well, soon to our panel, but as a sort of a kind of an introduction or set up for our panel, I would like to introduce John Horrigan. John is a senior fellow at the--at the Technology Policy Institute where he focuses on technology adoption and digital inclusion. Dr. Horrigan is also a senior advisor to the Urban Libraries Council, so John, take it away.

HORRIGAN: Great. Thank you very much to everyone. I have a few slides that I think are going to get loaded and displayed in a minute. That is slide number one. We can go to the next slide, and what I want to do is offer a fairly high-level portrait of where we stand when it comes to the digital divide. What my focus is going to be is on internet adoption at home so my presentation will not get into the deployment issue, meaning I won't get into whether people's home broadband speed meet the 25 megabits per second threshold or not I'm just going to focus on what we know about how people or whether people are subscribing to broadband at home.

So in addition to this being St. Patrick's Day it also marks the 10th anniversary of the delivery of the National Broadband Plan to Congress and one of the things that is an outgrowth of a lot of the policy activity of that era is that the American community survey started in 2013 asking questions and it surveys about people's technology use at home. So that has become an incredibly rich data source on what is going on with respect to the digital divide in so far as we can now understand who is subscribing to broadband at home, who is not and even get down to the regional and city level to look at broadband adoption in those contexts.

I am going to keep it at the 30,000-foot level and just focus in this first slide on figures from the American community survey that focus on broadband of any type and the percentage of people with broadband of any type at home, and you can see over the 2013 to 2018 timeframe we have had a steady increase in the share of people with broadband of any type at home. We have gone from about 73 percent in 2013 to 85.1 percent in 2018. Let's go to the next slide, please.

On this next slide, we focus on American community survey data of--that takes a different slice at who has broadband at home. In 2016 the ACS started asking a question about whether people have broadband at home such as cable modem, digital subscriber line service, or fiber-optic service. That is a question that essentially captures the percent of people with a wireline broadband subscription at home, and you can see that the numbers are very different than when you focus on overall broadband adoption rates.

If you look at the 2018 number on the right, we see that 69--69.6 percent of households have a wireline broadband subscription at home. If you can remember back one slide prior, you will recall that in 2018 85.1 percent of Americans had broadband of any type, so you have that roughly 15 percentage point gap between people having broadband of any type versus a wireline broadband subscription at home. For the most part, that 15 percentage point gap is the smartphone, people who have a cellular data plan but do not have a broadband Internet subscription at home.

Now that gap is important because it is a measure of digital inequality. There's been a number of research undertakings, one of the most important most recently is from the Michigan State University, who show that having smartphone only internet access is insufficient for completing a number of different tasks online. The Michigan State research, in particular, households who are smartphone only have students in them who are struggling to complete homework, have lower levels of digital skills are less likely to take the SAT relative to those households with a wireline Internet subscription at home.

So the focus on the wire line subscription I think is an important metric for policymakers to focus on and we in turn translate that 69.6 percent figure into households. That means that as of 2018 in the United States, we had nearly 37 million households without a wireline broadband Internet subscription at home. And as I think many of us can appreciate, that wireline subscription is the pipe off of which so much of our Internet experience depends and it's where wireline ends and for my most households Wi-Fi begins.

Next slide, please. And Commissioner Rosenworcel set up a nice analogy that I'm going to play off of for this slide. As she pointed out how some households have super-fast Highway running to their homes and then with Wi-Fi that may not perform so well, they get off onto a gravel road. Well, this first data point from Deloitte survey shows that the average household has 11 wireless connected devices.

So there's a lot of cars on that gravel road relying on Wi-Fi for their Internet access experience and as the tool by which they use the various applications on these wireless devices. The Deloitte reports didn't break out how many low income households have connected devices relative to well off ones, but when you have an average of 11 wireless connected devices, it means that even low income households have a number of wireless connected devices sharing that Wi-Fi Internet connection at home.

And in fact, according to a survey I did and in 2018 of low income households, and this was a sample of Comcast Internet essentials customers who had come within the prior three months, gotten a home broadband subscription, we asked them what kind of devices they had, what kind of things they do with their home broadband subscription. We found that 82 percent had smart phones, 59 percent streamed TV or video to their devices, 57 percent had a desktop or laptop, 53 percent have a tablet. So low income households have lots of wireless devices.

I should point out also that the 59 percent number for streaming TV and video, obviously that does include entertainment, but we also found in that survey which did have an oversample of low income households with children. That survey did find that there was a lot of streaming going on for educational purposes in those households.

Let's turn for a second to Wi-Fi in community anchor institutions and, in particular, libraries. What I did at the Pew Research Center a couple of years back focused on how consumers will help patrons experienced various technology experiences at the local public library and we found that 29 percent of public libraries patrons use the library or Wi-Fi resources at the local public library. That was most prevalent among young people and low-income people and there was a high rate of people using Wi-Fi or other competing devices at libraries for schoolwork, research, and for healthcare applications.

I want also mentioned some work I've done looking at public libraries in California in the State of California several years ago, public libraries were able to access the Phoenix Research Network in the state, which is very high-speed Internet connection that runs to public libraries. This increased the access speeds available at public libraries from something like 76 megabits per second to 2 gigabits per second or more. So libraries were going from been with scarcity to been with abundance overnight in some cases and libraries had eight to consider what to do with this new wealth of bandwidth.

Lots of libraries started interesting programs on gaming in there--to bring people to libraries in their community to do gaming. They used their bandwidth for programs to import cultural content from some of the state's excellent cultural institutions like the Exploratorium or the Getty Museum in Los Angeles. So libraries started to close what we identified as a sort of this bandwidth imagination gap by using bandwidth for some of the services I just described but also relying on Wi-Fi within their libraries to really deliver those services.

So libraries in California at least, and I'm sure this is going on in other places around the country, are seeing sometimes very significant upgrades in connection speeds. They also need the next step, which is to have the Wi-Fi within their institutions to really get the most bang for the bandwidth buck that they're getting.

Next slide, please. And this will just be by way of wrapping up to talk about some of the implications of this. For a lot of people, the last few feet is as important as the last mile to their households. This is true in particular for all income categories. Wi-Fi 6 is part of another tech transition but we have to make sure that the capacity exists to serve all segments of society.

So there's an imperative and we're seeing it obviously very vividly in these recent days with people having to stay-at-home due to the pandemic to work on the problem of home wireline broadband connectivity to lots of low income Americans in particular, but then also plan for the future with a Wi-Fi experience that will make--enable people to get the most out of the bandwidth that we have at home. So with that, I will wrap up, Michael, and to turn it over to you.

CALABRESE: Thanks, John. That's--yeah, that was terrific background and I think, you know, for me at least particularly reinforced--I wasn't aware that scenic (SP), the California libraries in scenic example, but it really dramatizes that, you know, you can have--you can bring multi-gigabit, you know, fiber to a community anchor institution library, school, but if you can't distributed to all the devices, to all the people and, you know, you're really not making the most of it. And with 5G applications, we'll only get bandwidth intense, obviously AR, VR, the things that Priscilla outlined for us earlier.

So let's move--move on then to include the rest of our--our panel and I'll just introduce each one in turn for, you know, just kind of a few minutes of, you know, their perspective on, you know, why are they in their organization so engaged on this--on this issue, why is it important. So first we have Paula Boyd, who is the--who is the senior director for government and regulatory affairs at Microsoft.
